pros: Culture is really coming along at IBM. Parts of the company have done a lot to advance towards current trends. There has been solid flexibility during the pandemic, and tons of support.
cons:
Like all giant corporations, change is slow. Leadership often feels the need to validate their existence by micromanaging. That is slowly going by the wayside, but patience is a must if you seek to make a worthwhile career at IBM.
Advice to Management
Growing a team doesn’t always mean adding a manager. Empower your teams, advance from within, and continue towards an open and honest culture.

review_title: Great for learning. Ho-hum on salary and benefits
cons:
ltant in Manila, Manila, Manila
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
*Mostly competent people I've worked with from different backgrounds and age ranges.
*Very good tools (W3 portal) one-stop shop for all HR/Expenses/Appraisal/Tech support needs 
*Excellent learning culture where IBM will sponsor your certifications for free and even reward you for passing them. Free Udemy and SAP Learning Hub access.
*Flexible work from home arrangement.
*In the pandemic we have received some food reimbursements and an internet allowance.
Cons
*Some projects give incentives if you did a great job. Otherwise the salary is mostly stagnant.
*The org structure is already very lean (minimal managers / lead positions), 1 project manager with direct reports, for example - so the chances of being promoted vertically (with a paygrade increase) is very slim.
Advice to Management
*Revisit the salary and benefits of your employees and re-align it with the industry.

pros: Tech stack is better than you might expect. They use the latest in cloud, artificial intelligence, and other skills.
cons:
Absolutely all things claimed to be done by Silicone Valley will be summarily implemented regardless of whether they apply to the specific situation. You'll spend much more time on compliance than productive work. Pay is at the lower end of what you could get. No raises or bonuses. Health insurance is more costly than average, barely less than hourly contract workers. HR will not share this publicly because it is so bad. They have an agile environment, you might find yourself like an ancient Egyptian slave building a useless pyramid under the whip of some under-educated "scrum master" who can barely turn on a computer.
Advice to Management
Stop trying assuming and treating software engineers like worthless commodities. They are only commodities because you value them as such.

ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
1. They promised a lot of different things when you are hired
2. Pay is ok but only for the very first time
3. You will be getting a lot of e-mail from senior management with absolutely the same mantra - "We appreciate a lot that you do for IBM", "Without you, IBM is nothing" etc. But as stated below - there is nothing but a pure lie to keep the motivation of employees
Cons
An unexpectedly huge number of conses which is absolute nonsense for such a company like IBM:
1. Hire to fire mentality. That is ridiculous but you are hired only for a short period of time (and you'll be fired right after the project will ended). Nobody cares about your next assignment - neither your manager nor anyone at IBM - you are the only one responsible for finding a project (and you will see a constant punishment from different management). It results in the pre-sales activities that you must do, which contradicts what IBM promised you to do.
2. A lot of departments with noble names (Cloud innovation, etc.), with a lot of management, which does nothing. Departments just tried to find their own client and do everything the client requested - no matter what kind of activities it might be - from the solution development to the pure business consultancy. So nobody cares about what project you would like to be engaged in - you will work otherwise you'll be fired.
3. Salary raise. Just forget about it - it happens bizarrely rare. For instance, people working for IBM did not have a raise for about 3 or 4 years even though got an upper level of performance.
4. People. Most of your colleagues - as worked under a punishment - have treats you wouldnt' like. They might be lying, arrogant, lazy, they don't care about other people's problems. That is the real IBM 'soul'


All that just lead to enormous frustration and burnout, you cannot have plans for your employment more than for the period of the project are working for..

As a technical person - I extremely do not recommend that place. It is worse than any outsourcing company.
Advice to Management
The only advice is to completely transform yourself into the software development company and fire all of the middle management, transforming the team to agile. 
The company that fires experts instead of management - is sick and will die in any case.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: A dying company with a declining culture
pros: There are still some very talented colleagues
cons:
The company is in a steady decline and it is bringing out the worst in people. Very competitive, sharp elbows and limited trust and collaboration. Expect significant layoffs and budget cuts every other year. Marketing platforms are poorly implemented and not ready for prime time. Requirements are being defined by people with limited to no experience. It’s a big mess.
Advice to Management
Stop with the fake rah rah and do something about the horrible culture . No one is happy and most are afraid or getting laid off or are just working to add something to their resume when they jump ship to their next role outside the company.

review_title: Good first job. Overall not a great experience.
pros:
Great place to network and meet like minded individuals.
Good place to gain insight into the business side of software contract work.
Good position to add to your resume.
cons:
I can break down the cons of my experience at IBM CIC Baton Rouge into 3 categories: 1. Pay 2. Management. 3. Projects 

1. The pay at the Baton Rouge CIC is low comparatively and relatively. I personally worked there for ~3 years, and was still earning under $50k annually as a developer. 

 2. Management is out of touch with the developers. When things don’t go as planned, management fails to take ownership over developers. Overall, management doesn’t care about developers. They only seem to care about developers charging hours to a project so they meet their numbers. These, among other, managerial issues are deeply rooted in the CIC. I have seen similar issues brought up to upper management, and sadly, little or nothing is done to address the issue's root cause. Instead management’s usual solution is to throw the CIC a pizza party or send you cookies to show you that they “care”.

3. I worked on 6 different projects while at the CIC, and only 2 of the 6 were quality. One of the “projects” I was assigned was for RI Dept of Health working as a call center operator scheduling covid tests for kids and teachers. Overall quality of projects is not great.
Advice to Management
Take ownership. Truly listen to your employees. More competitive pay.

review_title: Good work life balance - Top is laden with politics
pros:
Great work life balance 
Leadership and colleagues are in general friendly
cons:
Top is laden with politics - I've seen two types of leaders: 
1. people who rise to the top because they are great leaders 
2. people who rise to the top because they have great relationships (but are not great leaders at all) 
Unfortunately type 2 has been much more common at IBM 
As a result, young, ambitious folks who work a lot, who are fully capable, often face a "glass-ceiling" at this company as they lack the sponsors/relationships
Advice to Management
Focus on growing the next generation of talents and leaders based on meritocracy 
Need to practice what we say we are on values, cultures

pros: A formidable training ground as there is aridiculous amount of traininng options through internal platforms and lots of potential coaches very open to share their expertise. Great cross cultural exchange as you work with people from literllaly all over the world. Very good benefits plan.
cons:
A bit too bureaucratic for my taste. Focus is not truly on performance but mostly on measurements and reaching specific indicators for the area. Changing roles is quite a challenge and there is a lot of push back from the business unit to let go of a practitioner to another area (two examples: one person had to negotiate for over 1 year and essentially stop doing her job to be allowed to move to another role, another made 3 attempts where she was told that there was no problem with moving, but had to wait 6 months to do so). 
Locally, management still needs development; in my personal experience, feedback from management was, with 2 exceptions (noting that I reported to 6 different managers in a little over a year), simplistic, sometimes recycled and never clear on which gaps needed improvement to further advance your career. Managers in general tend to be too nice and try to avoid making you feel bad rather than challenging you to become a better professional.
Advice to Management
Pay more attention to what your team members are saying and focus less on their numbers when discussing development. And get to the point without so much fuss.

pros: Work From Home is available depending on type of work. High on diversity. Free online learning course. You will learn to stay relevant and competitive in a fast paced environment.
cons:
Expect very seldom career growth opportunity. Be ready to accept more work and responsibility. Extended or long hours of work is a norm. You will experience many critical work days/periods in which you will not be able to take vacation leave. Best of luck if they happen to fall on an important family occasion. Senior management are usually too busy they can't schedule a decent or quality time for one on one meeting. If they do manage to schedule one, good luck on feeling the sincerity because more often it becomes robotic or routinely for compliance. Out of 10 managers I have experienced on my entire career only 2 managers which was during my early years were able to show sincerity and genuine concern about me as an employee and my career development. Over the years, I have seen how the work culture declined. What was once a happy, sharing of best practices and helping each other type of work environment became a highly competitive one. People became focused on job security because of the rampant and aggressive company or business operation changes. My advise is to check back after 2-3 years when they are probably more stable.

review_title: Was a great place for many years, but it's not the same
pros:
Compensation including salary and benefits packages.
Teaming, International cooperation, and cultural acceptance made for great experiences.
Process centric taught me a great deal about business and best practices methodologies.
cons:
No salary increases for years combined with increasing work demand was a real spirit breaker.
Increasingly difficult to get promotions regardless of physical performance as it was standard practice to lower performance ratings when there was no budget for raises or rewards. 
IBM is very strategic about what they offer in severance packages to ensure a reduced media coverage by fewer complainers. 
IBM is known to not favor senior staffers. Why pay someone $145k, when they can help you out the door and immediately hire a college intern that has no practical business skills for far less.
Advice to Management
Speak less of the harnessing of skills from senior staff when you actually prefer to allow the bean counters to trim he expenses and worry about expertise after the fact. Yes this is what impacted me, but at the same time for years prior, I saw this happen to colleagues all the time. I should have left earlier for opportunities with competitors to help put you in your place.

ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Easy work, reasonable hours, pay is OK given hours
Cons
It's pretty much what you would expect from your assumptions of IBM. Work is dull, management are dull and very few people actual like working there. The graduate program is terrible, the only meaningful difference between being a graduate and not seems to be that you have three two-day training session which are a complete waste of time. Nobody really cares about your development, the only aim of management seems to be to get your utilisation numbers high. Even if this means staffing you on projects where you are not needed. 

If you are lucky you may find interesting work as it is a big company, however, the experience of myself and the vast majority of my peers was that the work is poor, development opportunities are poor, and you will spend a significant proportion of your time quite bored.

pros: They provide a decent salary for entry level. I had a very good experience with this company. All people are nice and professional. Knowing I was just a fresh graduate when I worked there, they believed my capabilities and supported me all throughout my journey. My team helped me build my confidence and thought me so much values that would make me mature and professional just like them. I'll missed the atmosphere and culture that might be difficult to find in other companies. As for the job, I was challenged and overwhelmed at first because I had to learn many systems and tools. But I get eventually used to it. Even I find it somehow routinary but I enjoyed working with the process. I thank this company for believing in me and the trust they bestowed in me.
cons:
This company thrives in innovation. There's no way you should stay on what is permanent because they change everything in a short matter of time. Too bad when I already learned a process or work, I will pour my heart on that job and perform the best I can be on that process. Also, I am introvert and I prefer to keep everything as silo as it could be but I guess almost all corporation has this culture of collaboration and negotiation which I do not possess. I also felt the company values are not aligned with mine so I eventually get depressed and sad when I wake up everyday and not so excited to log in knowing my day will have so much meetings left and right. Not to mention extending my time because I had to meet our counterparts from different timezones so work-life balance is somehow compromised.
Advice to Management
I find it odd sometimes when you always try to change something even if there's nothing to be changed. I always try not to invalidate the great things you've done to the world. People will always be thankful for those. But based on my experience at IBM, I find your culture of innovation somehow superficial and just a 'decoration' since I observed that you've been pressured by your competitors in the tech industry. And so you're hurrying to innovate on something, change on something, create this company, and this and that... But I would like to tell you from the very bottom of my heart.. you have the power to make job market a dynamic and harmonious one than empowering only your industry/area of specialization. There are people who do not care in material gains and status just like me. But I guess since IBM is an American company so the culture of competition and superflous idea of recognition are there. I am just an average middle income guy whose become a failure of the system I can't able to adapt. But the system also forgot to cater to people of different values and principles because they neglect to align that with their system. I hope you find it in your heart how the most silo and introverted people in the world can make a difference if your system open their arms for these kind of people.
Be the first to find this review helpful

ltant in Los Angeles, CA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
IBM is no longer the uptight blue suit wearing company of the past. I expected a far more rigidly managed culture of conformity but what I have experienced is rather open, friendly and relaxed. Ability to apply your subject matter expertise with a great amount of autonomy while working with clients if excellent for experienced professionals.
Cons
Administrative processes take the concept of employee self-service to the extreme. Many internal systems are old, overengineered and occasionally just don't work at all. It can be both difficult and frustrating to find a human to help. With all that said the biggest Con of working for IBM is the email and scheduling platform (Lotus Notes or something called Verse). Outlook, Gmail or really anything else would be more effective and efficient. Its really that bad.
Advice to Management
Let go of Notes and Verse. Really anything else would be more effective and efficient.

review_title: Good company for learning and work-life balance
pros:
* Ample opportunities to learn
* Good work-life balance
* You can switch to new roles in same band
* Appreciation and recognition is a culture
cons:
* Manager driven company, high performance is not valued unless manager recommends
* Growth is project based, you can not understand if the account has growth opportunity
* Your Band Promotion is very difficult even manager agrees but finance does not
* There is no HR process to initiate promotion even after spending 5 / 6 years in same band (at least till band 7) and fulfilling all the requirements to get a promotion
Advice to Management
Appreciation is a good culture but if people are not growing, they tend to leave the company. A loss if IBM experience and skill-set can not make good to the company. Please don't always blindly depend on people managers.

review_title: Hard graft and most people go unrecognised
cons:
ltant in London, England, England
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Good solid training that sets you up really well for a career elsewhere
Good exposure to clients and new projects. Strategy is fun if you have a good partner at the helm of the RFP.
Cons
Culture is toxic & predatory. Diversity is a joke. The hours are long which I didn't mind but I can understand that this is not everyone's cup of tea, so you find yourself picking up the slack for others. The internal processes are mind-boggling time-consuming. The penalties for not doing each process are severe for what is essentially low-value red tape.

CEO Approval

Pros
- Highly innovative projects

Cons

- Poor prospects for technically focused individuals as incentive scheme sadly does not reward technical excellence

- Hire senior staff with hard skills

review_title: Not recommended in GBS for people who would like to learn and grow
pros: They provide laptops on first day.
cons:
Poor management in GBS
They provide laptop and ask us to lock inside Office Premises then why a portable device is provided? 

There was a situation where management told us "You can be scientist or excellent engineer but here you must do what we ask to do". 

HR and managers are same person so it is difficult to reach HR in case of any issues. 
Lot of politics happen as HRs support only managers. 
I have seen pure politics and people literally suffered. 
Having laptop in hand, management expects people to work whenever it is asked. They expect to be logged in 24 / 7. 
They used Whatsapp as official chat and impacted personal life of so many people. 
These are the cons in my experience with IBM.
Advice to Management
Look up for employees and value their personal life. Some standards should be in place.

review_title: Not a great experience, but not representative of all sections of IBM.
cons:
ltant Data Scientist in Washington, DC
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Competitive salary, work-life balance, collaborative culture. I didn't enjoy my business unit, but I met a number of supportive individuals very satisfied with their careers who took the time to speak with me. I would not be opposed to returning to a different line of business.
Cons
Competitive advantage in larger, multi-year projects which can offer less professional development for skills sought out in more innovative tech companies. I didn't find the work to be challenging or stimulating - I did find some people that would have listed this as a 'pro' which is also disappointing.
Advice to Management
I was disappointed in how I perceived HR to handle a sexual harassment case reported by a peer. Without details, I consider the decision by the HR investigator to be retribution against the victim in an attempt to intimidate her from taking further action. This fully negated any positive experience I had with the company and I think the policy, if implemented correctly, is an ethical failure.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: WFH set up. Internet reimbursement.
cons:
Worst company I've ever worked with. Considering how big this company is, you expect them to give you the best compensation and best support. But this is not what you expect them to be. They are abusive, forcing you to work even more even though you already have a lot on your plate. Inconsiderate to their employees. Management knows where they are lacking but they just don't care. They just want you to do the impossible then won't even pay you what you deserve. Extremely low salary increase. No bonuses. Until resignation, they will outsmart you. 2 months is the render period then they will hold your salary also for that 2-month period. Just thinking of themselves. Not even a little sympathy on their employees. You won't even dare to come back to this kind of company. Very cruel and not fair. I regretted that I've been in this company.
Advice to Management
GIVE THE SALARY THAT EMPLOYEES DESERVE. DON'T ABUSE THEIR SKILLS AND ENERGY WITHOUT GIVING THEM PROPER COMPENSATION. WHAT KIND OF MANAGEMENT ARE YOU?

pros: So many resources available. Lots of white space to learn new skills. Mentors at IBM that I had were the smartest I’ve ever had. If you can get in the right room, you can make a huge impact.
cons:
The culture is incredibly dated, and the ability to grow in the marketing side of the organisation is really tough. Speaking on behalf of the UK office. My recommendation to young employees is to build your skills to your best ability, and leave so you can make a decent salary elsewhere and come back at a more senior level.
Advice to Management
Don’t hinder young people’s growth because they aren’t taking the same path you have / are moving more quickly than you’re accustomed to. Give them the tools to thrive, and let them be the change and refresh this organisation so desperately needs.

pros: Work life balance guaranteed at IBM. IBM Cloud solutions have already been introduced into various parts of the UK’s National Health Service, contributing to the efficient and secure running and delivery of care to patients. One such example is NHS Blood and Transplant (NHSBT) which employs IBM Business Process Manager (BPMoC) and Operational Decision Manager on Cloud (ODMoC) to maximise utility within the organisation’s structure. There are multiple benefits, and include the streamlining of delivery, maximised utilisation and equity of organ allocation nationwide, and the freeing up of vital resources. October 2015 was a seminal moment for the partnership, with the first transplant of a heart allocated according to the new scheme taking place. Innovation did not halt there, and NHSBT is exploring additional possibilities afforded by IBM’s cloud solutions, including expanding platform capabilities to encompass kidney and pancreas transplants.
cons:
Locked with IBM cloud and tools in most of the IBM core projects

pros: Huge company so there's lots of opportunity to move around or try new departments.
cons:
The pay is average to low and there are layoffs a few times a year. Although I was there 20 years there is considerable stress about the frequent layoffs, particularly if you're over 50. I had a great manager but coworkers frequently complained about their managers.
Advice to Management
There is a clear focus on attracting younger, cheaper employees. This comes at a cost to intellectual property. Frequent employee turnover also means too much time is spent on-boarding new hires. It also doesn't foster employee loyalty. Young guns stick around 2-4 years then take the better offers $$.

cons:
ltant in New York, NY
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Working at IBM you're always (if you're in the right group) surrounded by smart people who can teach you a lot - about tech, running projects, and turning projects around. The WLB is also good, and direct management definitely seems to care about you as a person.
Cons
There is a culture of mediocrity (slow and steady would be the nicer way to put it), that seems leftover from the old days when 30 years at IBM guaranteed you a full pension. For the most part, managers seem surprised when you ask what it takes to get promoted quickly. It's hard to get straight answers, and frequently the manager who gave you advice winds up leaving by the time they suggested you get promoted.
Advice to Management
Make it crystal clear what is expected from each band level, and what a consultant has to do to get promoted. Transparency is helpful, so better yet publish standard salary ranges for each band too (ignoring outliers, like 15 YOE band 8's). If you want to keep top performers around, you need to compensate them properly, and make the career growth path visible.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros:
As a fresher good company to join.
Good work life balance.
Provides free Udemy courses
cons:
My experience working with IBM was really very disappointing. I am not lucky enough to be under good management unlike most IBMers .

As a fresher after 4 months I was assigned to a project where only 2 developers are there in a project. After 3 months my senior left, all things came on my shoulder. I was given good reviews for Project work but got least hike and reason was very funny.
My father got sick I asked for location change . They told they will do, but didn't keep their words each time asked for update on that came with various reasons. In between covid came so wfh was there. I worked in additional hours (US times) but no shift allowance I got. Previous year I was waiting for good hike, since most of the project deliverables was of mine. Against it was disappointing hike. I decided to move on, after got some offers I resigned. Then they offered me good hike along with my preferred location, I but denied straight way. In my case neither they appreciated hard work nor kept their words regarding working location change. One more thing was I took sick leave since I got conjunctivitis, later they deducted this from my Planned leave for something because of project utilization as a team (don't know what actually it is) which was really unique. But some of my friends are under good management, they are not facing similar things.
Advice to Management
Should respect and care about theiremployees

pros: You can change paths in your professional career without leaving the company. A great place to work and grow professionally and as a person. Excellent values and ethics.
cons:
Complex and sometimes bureaucratic, too many middle managers, Directors, VPs reporting to other VP, GMs to GMs. The organization matrix is confusing.
Advice to Management
The company can cut a lot of the extra layers of management (Executives), save money, and gain agility.
 Employee -> Manager -> Director -> VP -> GM 
The only layer with no duplication in titles & job responsibility is the Employee -> Manager; after that, there is tons of duplication in the Org chart.

review_title: Probably the most humane and definitely the best place I've worked for, so far!
pros:
Proper IBM'ers inside and outside! Ethics, Understanding, Quality of people, Helpful inside work and even more helpful outside work and on personal circumstances!
I will never forget in my life what IBM CIC UK have done for me and this feedback is the least I can do, to be honest.
cons:
It is a consultancy and client facing environment and employees tend to jump from project to project or client to client. Especially these COVID days we are going through, clients tend to easily and without a second thought, pull the plug out of projects. This make CIC'ers go back to bench and start from scratch, looking for their project/client.
It is tough but challenging!
Advice to Management
Do not let bossy clients run, intervene or interfere with OUR projects! This is exactly what CIC Management do, at their best!

pros:
Great at attracting good talents and good brand value. 
Opportunity to work with clever people around.
Most employees are proud of being IBMers and be part of the great legacy.
cons:
- No structured working hours, people are often working late in the office (it could be their personal routine to meet deadlines)
- Always last-minute communication about Organisational and structural changes.
- Very small or no increments at all as department budget squeezes each year.
- Even hot water costs money along with Coffees, Tea, etc (London Southbank office)
Advice to Management
Lots of innovative ideas at the top management which is great but saw no real benefits at the ground level. 
Senior management could be more approachable and agile.

review_title: Less opportunities, poor processes and purely transactional
pros: Learning and professional development, Global exposure, Partnerships with all major technology players and good foot hold on opensource software. Open culture with relatively greater importance to business conduct.
cons:
In the name of high value opportunities tendency of partners is to over-commit and get aggressive with offshore teams. 
No growth opportunities, people do get their career stagnated here. Client centric decentralized org, difficult to navigate where all the power is given to the people manager. Lack of transparency and no free flow of information within the organization.
Advice to Management
Reduce the power distance, move away from sales approach for survival and provide career path that transcends BUs, that motivates innovation.

cons:
of working with IBM
16 Aug 2021 - Anonymous Employee 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
-Better work from home opportunities for those who cannot travel to office.
-Flexible work environment.
-Shift Allowances are provided. 
-Training modules on upcoming technologies are really good.
Cons
-Good salary hike is "only" provided when you first join the organisation, in between promotions and hike is not even in sight after joining.
-Band system does not align well with the number of experience a person has which may be little demotivating.
-Difficult to reach out to HR regarding any professional queries.
Advice to Management
-Aligning the band with the years of experience would be really helpful and motivate the employees to contribute better.
-Projects which are running remotely should be made mandatory to have team events to have better team co-ordination and work motivation.

pros:
IBM is one of the best places to work if you want to learn and get a head start of new technologies and expand your knowledge. Their learning portal is incredible and they dedicate enough attention for this area.

cons:
Not all projects you enter will meet your expectations from the technical level so you have to constantly work in initiatives inside the company to maintain your technical practicality towards the concepts you learn in courses.

Good benefits but pay is borderline.

review_title: Layoffs is like a yearly event for IBM.
pros:
-Good medical benefits

-Pay is on par (or higher) than market rate. 

-A lot of free resources to learn a lot of thing (e.g. new technology, leadership skills, communication skills, etc)

-Cultural Diversity where you get to work with people from different culture, different background, different countries.
cons:
-Too many "dotted line" reporting layers other than your direct upline manager. 

-Constantly re-org disrupted the effort put when you're onto a specific role and job mission.

-No point working hard or being loyal as they constantly lay off employees even thought the team is performing well. 

-Encountered a leader who was constantly playing politics to other team or even to own team instead of focusing on his work. Any new company out there hires this leader in the future likely going to waste their money. Good luck!
Advice to Management
-Remove all unnecessary dotted line reporting and those complex multi-layered unnecessary reporting restructure. 

-Review your business strategy instead of constantly re-org or laying off your employees who fought and worked hard for your company.

ltant in Baton Rouge, LA
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
I liked my teammates, my manager and my benefits. Had more good experiences than bad, but I had to get out of there in order to advance my career in Workday.
Cons
Utilization always came first before talent development, quality of projects was poor and IBM core was already stretched for senior level Workday consultants because many of them already left. There was also no structure for advancement or learning if you were new. No mentors, or training path. There was no way to get yourself off the bench to pick up more hours doing other Workday projects or post production support. You get placed where your manager decides they need the billable hours most. Sometimes you are forced to get "cross trained" and never get to do Workday again. Other Workday partners don't operate like this. I don't recommend if you're new to Workday.
Advice to Management
Overhaul your Workday practice. Model it like other partners. Give new consultants structure for advancement, stop denying them training, and do what other partners are currently doing better.

review_title: Should be Last option for Graduate hires / Freshers (GBS/GTS Domain)
pros:
Work From Home facility
Good number of program runs for up-skill or re-skill
Bit flexible in terms of timings, basically depends on your manager.
Unlimited sick leaves, actually it is not unlimited but of-course better than other MNCs where they have counts.
Cab facilities for Girls/Women after 7 PM.
IBM in other countries are way better than the India, in terms of work culture and pay.
cons:
1. Very Low compensation compare to market
2. Three Months Notice Period
3. Yearly increment is in single digit or no increment until you are manger favorite.
4. If you are traveling to onsite / coming back from onsite , you will not get that year hike.
5. Though company runs multiple programs to up-skill but if you want to do a certification of other technology where manger approval required and is not currently being used in the account , Managers won't approve.
6. If by chance you resign during Jan-March. 90% of you will not get your PA and GDP i.e. whatever good work you have done for that financial year, the PA and GDP money which comes during March will not be given. Such a shame!!
Advice to Management
Stop doing favorism and partiality among employees
Be genuine
Take care of your employees because they run your company actually
Just think if the same happens to your close-one. How would you feel? At last Karma will pay.

review_title: Avoid IBM at all costs unless entry level or expecting children
pros:
- Parental leave benefit is really good (12 weeks paid)
- Learning opportunities for entry level workers, though some of this will be trial by fire
cons:
- Terrible work/life balance and little regard for employees mental health or wellbeing 
- You are expected to take on roles that are well outside your abilities and preferred career path
- Dramatic understaffing on projects as a means to improve margins 
- All the good resources are leaving, meaning there are no good mentors and everyone is being forced into roles they’re not capable of (see second bullet point above)
- IBM’s obsession with cross and upselling at all costs has led to building Frankenstein ecosystems that don’t work well or provide true value to clients. It’s disheartening to be worked to the bone to build something you’re not proud of 
- HR more or less does not exist and every internal system and process is as convoluted and confusing as possible. It’s amazing the company can even function given how poorly it is run
Advice to Management
It feels like it’s too late for management to fix all the issues, avoid IBM if you want a fulfilling career

review_title: No raises, no bonuses, and will work you to death and still ask for more
pros: If you enjoy not having any sort of personal life, than being an IBM service technician is for you. My normal hours are Monday thru Friday 8-5 and on call one week and weekend a month. In the evening and on the weekends, you’ll have the opportunity to be harassed by customers, dispatchers and management trying to get you to leave your home and family to go service a machine. They sell 24/7 coverage but yet have nobody working past 5pm. They rely on us monitoring our phones when we are off the clock. It’s a great system and a great company to work for..... so much so, that I am willing to take a cut in pay and benefits in order to get the heck away from IBM. 9 years with them and it gets worse every day.
cons:
No personal or family life... at all. Every plan you make will be ruined. Not enough staff to cover evenings or nights anymore so your subject to working any old time they call u. You have to literally request off your weekends if you want to do anything and even then you will be pressured and harassed to work because of the number of customers wanting service on the weekend and not enough people to do the work. Our new CSP system has created a ton of barriers to even do the job. Folks all over the world are ordering parts for us and are sending them all over the place and then we are on the hook to track them down. If you want pertinent info for the ticket, you have to drill down into several different menus... it’s terrible and has made an already tortured life at IBM that much worse. I wouldn’t tell my worst enemy to come work here it’s so bad. Everyone on my team hates this job with a passion and most retired the moment they could. The ones left can’t keep up anymore and working 30 hours overtime every week is getting old. Oh yeah, health insurance has gone up so much since Obamacare came out years ago, that I’m now on the “emergency” plan with hsa because it would be almost 500 a month for me and 2 kids on the good plan I used to be on. Dental is 130 a month for me and 2 kids. We used to get a small bonus every year of a thousand or less (before taxes) and they managed to take that away from us to. Being a technician for IBM is the bottom of the barrel. We are the red headed step children that IBM doesn’t give 2 craps about yet we are the ones who actually see the clients face to face. Guess what, I have nothing good to say about IBM to clients when I’m around them. Sorry for the rant, but I just worked all day Saturday and then had a code upgrade project that ran all night into Sunday and didn’t get home until 6am. Funny thing is, that’s normal for us these days and it shouldn’t be. There is NO limit to how much they will make you work.
Advice to Management
They don’t want to hear advice from an IBM peasant like me. They only listen to the yes men that surround them. Funny how they still get their bonuses but the peasants got theirs taken away

review_title: In hindsight, it was the highlight of my career. I left too soon.
pros: Cool career opportunities, brilliant people, patent groups, innovation isn’t just a buzzword, talent literally everywhere, commitment to design thinking, true professionals, instant camaraderie and a network that lasts beyond your time there, the most diverse culture, the first place where a senior engineer offered to mentor me as a designer
cons:
Sometimes you feel like a number, but only when random layoffs happen that impact star employees, it’s a corporate environment and that can feel stuffy
Advice to Management
I enjoyed my experience at IBM and only wish I had the benefit of hindsight before I decided to leave in the middle of a life event. My career experience since leaving has not been nearly as exciting or fulfilling and working for other companies since has really made me appreciate how well IBM really does it. I still talk about my experiences there and am so proud of what our teams did together.

pros:
Multicultural environment with friendly people in it, I barely met people I would have had negative opinion of (at least not in our region). Overall company culture is really good - every day respect of others is essential.
Good company to start with. Good place for those who need to see, experience the friendly and respectful cultural attitude.
cons:
Too much effort to plant the Big Blue Family vision in to the heads of employees - family is one and only and work is "only" work. Employees should feel good, safe and professionally performing their best knowing that they can lean on the company in terms of guaranteeing their future - I did not feel that and saw too much so called "resource actions".
Too much additional tasks to fulfill in a year, think40 / badges, honestly I barely met people who took that seriously and not because it is useless but because in this region it does not really gets you any further in your career.
Most of the times you have to change department / position to get higher in ranking and get better compensation, it has a negative side as well because if you get too high no department will want you to employ due to higher ranking / compensation range.
I have not seen attractive motivational assets during my career in IBM, bonuses are on the level of a joke, cafeteria is one of the lowest comparing to other companies.
Advice to Management
Local management: keep trying and fighting for better benefits and compensation for employees - guaranteed annual salary raises.

pros: Good place to gain experience and skills for entry level hires. They used to have a great remote/teleworking program, but took it away in an effort to pare down their workforce. A year or so later the pandemic happened, so they were already in a good spot to reinstate full time remote employment.
cons:
Those over 40 need not apply. Health insurance for old employees costs too much so they will target you in a resource action. Don't assume that you'll be making 6 figures by the time you get to that age either.
Advice to Management
I wish I had some that would save this company, but I fear that it's too late to save this sinking ship.

Benefits are good but salary is not competitive after you've been there for a few years.

review_title: Nice company to work at and build your resume
pros: At IBM research you get the opportunity to change groups and join projects you like, that can allow you to change and redefine your career as times/interests change. They WANT you to learn, grow and contribute. Career change/evolution within the company itself is always possible.
cons:
For some reason for the past 10 years (2010 - 2020) you feel some parts of the company's technology (along with stock market capitalization) falling behind compared to competitors. It could be the dilemma of a leading incumbent to protect legacy tech. But, things are starting to change, hopefully, after the new CEO (Arvind Krishna)
Advice to Management
Mid-level executives (i.e. VP's) should stop protecting legacy sacred cows and embrace new technology. IBM could have been the leader in cloud if they had concentrated on it in late 2000's instead of emphasizing on-premise computing. 
To attract young workers, move work locations closer/into major cities.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Great Company to start a career
pros:
Flexible vacations
Good People
Amazing way to learn a certain technology and get proficient at it
Pay above average for a starting position with room to grow
cons:
Dissonance between upper management and field teams
Fully depends on what unit/product you are placed on. There are darlings that get all the funding.
High turnover of talent that leads to a cycle
Advice to Management
Not every product needs to have the same business model. Focus less on being "yes-men" to the higher ups and focus more on figuring out what the business model for each product should be and how to implement it. Otherwise you are creating a standard that is impossible to live up too.

pros: Remote work was nice. Although they didn’t pay for office equipment beyond your laptop and docking station. Want a nice chair? Pay for it yourself. Fast internet? Again it comes out of your pocket.
cons:
They didn’t pay for squat. 
Even though you may have been working 45 to 60 hours a week for the last three years, you only accumulate the “standard amount”. If you leave the company having took a couple of extra days, they will send you a bill for the difference.

If you are in sales, they will come up with every BS excuse they can not to actually pay you your commission.
Advice to Management
Stop screwing over people. You have low pay compared to industry standards. People stagnate unless they work 60 hours a week to become an STSM or DE. Get rid of your lying sales management. Pay the commissions people are promised and earn.

Oh and I left of my own accord due to the stress. They now are trying to hire two people to do the job I did for a relatively low wage.

pros: Hardworking Co-workers; Endless Education and Training Opportunities; Good Benefits; Somewhat flexible work hours to allow for work/life balance.
cons:
Management focuses on accomplishing immediate objectives with little focus on planning for future success; Too much focus on making exceptions to processes as opposed to finding permanent enhancements to improve productivity; Upper management not receptive to suggestions for improvement; Expectations to work long hours and over weekends and holidays.
Advice to Management
Managers need to focus on what they can do today to improve results in the future. Everyone is focusing on doing what it takes to get through each business quarter to make that business quarter objectives, and no focus on long term goals. Management is not aware how this type of management effects plans for personnel resources in the future. Revenue numbers are embellished to get from one quarter to other.

ltant in New York, NY
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
As an Associate Consultant that is new to the environment, this is a great opportunity to learn about what you like and what you don't like for a new position in Technology. Your role is to seek out opportunities while on your project am that will help the project and your client counterparts.
Cons
Your assigned manager makes or breaks your experience at IBM and unfortunately, many managers at IBM do not have the time to effectively mentor and nurture your professional development.
Advice to Management
Incentivize coaches to nurture the relationship between the Associate and Manager/BPM. This will greatly improve the culture.

pros: None. They're Just really bad.
cons:
Company has been around so long, and is so big, yet some how has no idea what it wants to be when it grows up.
You're just a number there.
Bad work life balance.
Management frequently doesn't has a clue about the things they are managing. 
To long of a chain for information to get from the frontlines to any level of management where change could be made, and even then that management would have no understanding anyway.
They buy companies, change them to be IBM, then all the employees of that company they just bought end up leaving. 
They are just a bunch of brighten companies that don't even know what each other is doing and don't mess in anyway. Often their own products to better on other clouds than IBM's own cloud.
Way too much red tape. Too hard to get simple things done.
Discriminatory environment. 
Don't even provide references...
Just avoid this place.
Advice to Management
Promote from within. 
Don't assign managers from other groups that have no real understanding of what they are even managing.
Listen more to the front lines and customers.
Do more to keep the employees of the companies you buy, they are the real asset.
More effort and a better system to have the companies you bought to work together on common goals. To much right hand not knowing what the left is doing. Customers also are frustrated by the complete internal disconnect.

pros: IBM has some great mentorship programs for individuals seeking to move up in the organization. They also have great benefits if you want to take advantage of all the programs they offer to their employees.
cons:
IBM gets in their own way. They make licensing hard for clients to understand. They are not flexible in their deployment models and they cultivate a disfunctional work environment with in the organization. They can seem like a bully to clients based on how their business units operate.
Advice to Management
They need to downsize their selling model so they don't have so many people in one org fighting for a dog bone. They also need to structure their territories so reps in the South aren't covering stuff in the North. It makes no sense.

pros: Center of Excellence was a great place for university hires to develop technical skills and network. Relocation packages (back in 2014). Many different teams you can work for, you can move teams annually if there's an opening. Long-standing culture of remote work. Flex days given to compensate for demanding work cycles. Having IBM on your resume still counts for something in 2021.
cons:
Paid under market value, discussions of a pay raise are not entertained. Promotions in title and responsibility only, without commensurate pay raise. Bonuses for high performers are trivial, <1%. 

Lack of communication during large, critical reorganizations. Regular layoffs, including veteran employees. Open positions are not filled year after year, those remaining take on the extra work. No strategies to work to improve or replace low performers, high performers take on the burden. 

Upper management create toxic work environment where employees are terrified to make mistakes. Pre-COVID: depending on who you report to, remote workers are told to relocate or find a new job - inconsistent across company. 

Finance works long hours and weekends during monthly/quarterly closes and planning cycles. There is no work/life balance during these busy cycles.
Advice to Management
Promote hard workers and high performers. Backfilling veteran employees with offshore resources and expecting the same quality work is not sustainable.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

pros: Big company benefits, plenty of room to move up.
cons:
Working for (some particular branches of) GBS means you'll never maintain the same tech on your resume. This made it somewhat rough finding another job. You will need to be adamant in communicating that you want to be on similar projects. If you're starting, try to choose a popular tech stack and stick with it. 

The branch I was in was definitely top heavy, promoting individuals that weren't particularly ready in my opinion.

While there is plenty of room to move up, the raises are slow going but I am very satisfied as a junior dev to mid working there.

Remember GBS does not reflect all of IBM!

review_title: Good pay and benefits, mature employees, boring culture
pros:
- Great experience
- Salary
- Benefits
- Big tech industry experience
cons:
- No one has cameras on, feels very impersonal
- Not a lot of care for early employees, no coaches or mentors
- Siloed within current business unit / org. No visibility into other businesses at IBM. Hard to feel connected to larger strategy.
- Very easy to feel unhappy or lonely in this role
- Much older crowd. Most people here already have kids or grandkids, so they don't take an effort to talk to other people or learn about new hires.
Advice to Management
Take more interest in small talk or conversations about personal lives. No one on my team knows my birthday, anything about my life, or congratulated me on my 1 year anniversary.

pros: No reason to work at a company that continually violates Federal Discrimination laws (search “Ibm discrimination”)
cons:
Something is terribly wrong when a company has at least annual layoffs (often 2 or more in a year) going back 10+ years. No genuine regard for their employees. No accountability in senior or middle management. If you are a part of an acquisition, you need to understand the clock is ticking until they start to include you in their “resource actions” (wake up Red Hat) especially if US based. Truly a shame that a once great company has devolved into shell of its former self.
Advice to Management
Hire a CEO that has a track record of successfully leading other companies. The current & previous had zero experience in that role & the results speak for themselves.

pros: Hugely inclusive, big emphasis on employee satisfaction, great work-life balance, a lot of resources, good to be part of a principled company that takes a stand, research is excellent, could have a dozen different carriers in one company
cons:
There is a disparate workforce with many young people and many people who have been with the company for decades. Generally though, leadership is very focused on growth mindset and modernizing.

cons:

IBM culture differs from a country to country. IBM Global sees some IBM country organizations as an internal customer and forces to use services from IBM India like cheap locations but this strategy causes two problems. 1) IBM India resources and the organization is terrible! and 2) Valuable technical resources in client! countries think that their value is not seen by IBM.

Most of IBM managers in edge country organizations just think their careers and behaves their employees like modern age slaves.
Advice to Management
Create an environment to monitor the facts! in all countries. Monitor the projects with negative profits!! and find the reason why some projects have negative profit and how it is hidden from IBM global!

Monitor the managers and their behaviors by keeping in touch directly with the employees! After Kyndryl, IBM will loose the direct contact to the customers which will create a huge gap between developers/central teams and the customers

review_title: Great Organization to Work and Learn
pros:
A great organization with 110 years of industry expertise, where you can learn anything you want and any can earn any certification you want.

Great product and services portfolio and great customer. Being honest almost all all the fortune 100 companies use IBM product.

Innovation and patent hub if you are a creative person.

Great work life balance, unlimited sick leave, and work from home facility.
cons:
As this is old organization, still have bureaucratic structure, which they are trying to get out of it. Still need more work. 
As per my understanding, Indian management is very poor, lack of vision and skill. 
Good customers are moving out, sales team is very poor and their attitude is squeezing the existing customer, not generating good sales. 
Poor career growth and hike. People try to stay due to work life balance.
Advice to Management
Please work on restructuring the business and operating model. Also, hire some good sales people, do good branding. 

Technology innovation is not working due to lack of vision for recent time. IBM into the cloud space in last 10 years but couldn't do anything due to poor offering.

Not taking up RDB in right time made Oracle to became largest,
selling up and splitting up business like networking, BPO, consumer business, managed infra is bad idea. It could have been restructured.

review_title: Workplace filled with lot of internal politics

- Flexible work hours and location
- Loads of learning content
- Exposure to latest technology if you are in right team
cons:
- Flexible work hours is taken as advantage by most of them
- Very poor hikes and benefits
- Career growth is only for those who showcase others hardwork and not for who really work hard
- No support from Management in all the aspects
Advice to Management
IBM would really grow if the Internal politics and Nepotism vanishes away, and if the right talent is given opportunities. Lot of people are promoted just for showcasing other's hardwork while they play a smart card game, this should end. Real talent should be identified and provided good support which will help company's real growth

pros: IBM was once a great company to work for. Pensions, good benefits, education reimbursement, training, great management, etc. Unfortunately, now this company is a shell of it's former self.
cons:
Pensions gone. Benefits slashed. Good luck on getting anything reimbursed (even internet access and phones for remote employees was cut). Horrible, toxic management so infested with workforce politics that even Queen Cersi from Game of Thrones would blush.

Employees are in constant fear of resource actions (RAs) and management is in a perpetual cycle of evaluating who the next person(s) to include on future RAs. (Forced rankings/PBC where employees have to compete against each other never went away).

IBM was late to cloud computing and never made any in roads to market share. Their technology is outdated and (offshore) customer support is horrible. There are many other fantastic Cloud companies to work for these days. Stay away. 

IBM has become irrelevant.
Advice to Management
Management is not listening to advice. The ship is sinking but they keep rearranging deck chairs and order the band to continue playing.

review_title: Best companies to explore different opportunities
cons:
ltant in New York, NY
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Agile culture, empowered employees and a culture of continuous learning and opportunities to grow in different roles to name a few
Cons
Hierarchical, too many layers, heavy on senior leadership, leadership selection process inconsistent without a focus on the right leadership fit and style to enable the growth behaviors we need to sustain change.
Advice to Management
1- re organize, remove the extra layers and connect the dots.. there is great opportunity for our process and workflow to be more intelligent and streamlined, to be one IBM.
2) Leadership selection and career progression. Select the right leaders, that will sustain the change we all want to see.
3) differentiating IBM - raising awareness of how are we different from our competitors, we should be using our own products and services, show how we have succeeded and can help our clients succeed.

pros: Variety of work; lots of challenges; structured approach to project implementation; immediate managers usually supportive; decent compensation and good benefits.
cons:
Trend towards offshoring means drastic headcount reduction in the UK especially for technical staff - seems to have accelerated in recent years, which is very demotivating.
Advice to Management
It may already be too late but for those UK technical resources that still remain - look at how much clients value having skilled people close to their business location as opposed to people located thousands of miles away. This may work for some functions but not for more involved support issues, or close project collaboration. Seems like a lot of business has been lost due to this issue.

cons:
ltant in Toronto, ON
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Loved being a part of the consulting training program for new university graduates. Helped me develop a network or peers and mentors which is required to thrive in such a big organization.
Cons
Missed opportunity for career development. It was quite often for consultants to get stuck on long projects at the expense of the development of those consultants' careers. This made the outcomes really bleak and resulted in a lot of great talent leaving.
Advice to Management
Find a better balance between meeting the needs of clients, the business and developing your talent.

Benefits are good, (HMO, Internet allowance & mobile allowance(Based on project))
Salary is fair, around what you would expect for a "good" starting salary. 
Environment (This is based on the people in my team) 
Supports WFH
Certifications, and badges are free (Udemy and IBM learning)
They implemented a Java Bootcamp for us for the hiring process, we did not finish it but we learned alot.
cons:
Upon passing the Java Bootcamp, they hold our employment til August/September even though other companies are already onboarding during the Pandemic.
Even though our bootcamp is for Java, most of us, including myself, did not get a Java position or atleast something programming related.
We are forced to work during weekends, prior to the client's request. 
No immediate OT pay.
If you're looking for a stable career path, think twice before entering here, there might be a possibility that you won't get what you want from the start or not at all.
Advice to Management
If you're going to put out a hiring a java position, and putting them in a java bootcamp, then make sure they get a java position or atleast something programming related.

pros: The company allowed working remotely due to the pandemic and provided free flu vaccination
cons:
The management showed prejudice between different departments. It's not easy to build a relationship as a team when the management doesn't set a good example. The manager also displayed favouritism behaviour and treated the team members unfairly, for example, someone abused the sick leaves but there was no disciplinary action taken against them. While others only took a few sick leaves but were penalised.
The managers lack basic leadership skills. They don't nurture or care about their staff, act like a bully when issues are raised. They also lack empathy and the ability to relate to the people who work for them. Other than that, they are not supportive for instance, if an employee is requesting a lateral move, they will give unreasonable excuses to prevent the employee from pursuing new and better opportunities. In addition, they make it difficult for people who wish to leave the company.
The company implement an archaic 'punched card' software in which you have to inform in writing how many hours you worked in a day including your leaves even after making the submission online. Other companies are using better software to keep track of the workforce management.
Advice to Management
Please hire competent managers who do have basic leadership skills and are able to guide their staff. Also, Pulse needs to be reviewed and the anonymity of the employee should be protected. That way, the company would know whether the manager might need more training.

pros: Management was great most of the time. We got 10 vacation and 6 sick days per year + 8 holidays. They matched compensation of my previous employer. They have a a lot of online classes you can take for free. you can work OT on projects if you want.
cons:
Supplemental employees didn't get raises, even after 4 years. No 401K match for Supplementals, so you really need to negotiate your salary up front because the bonuses they offer are only for the first 6 months. Even if you get promoted, you might not get a raise. Health insurance for Supplemental employees was horrible. The worst I have ever seen. Extremely high deductibles and out of pocket maximums(the amount you have to pay before everything is 100% covered).
Advice to Management
If someone isn't performing well, talk to them and let them know they need to do better, don't just lay them off without giving them a chance to improve some members of my team were let go very suddenly without being talked to 1st about their performance.

pros:
A lot of material to learn new technologies.

Different career plan programs, including IBM roadmaps and coaching, may meet people from other countries. You could work in a multicultural team.

Certifications paid for by IBM.

Good benefits.
cons:
Malinchismo and, sometimes, class discrimination.

It is not easy to move between business units to find a good plan for professional growth. You will not have any chance if the business unit does not want you to leave, although another business unit asks you to work in it, where you earn a better salary and learn the latest technologies. The best thing would be for you to have the right contacts to achieve a great professional growth plan.

There are some projects where the work-life balance is complicated due to poor project planning and organisation. There are other projects where the balance between personal and work life is perfect.
Advice to Management
Support for professional growth in different business units.

pros: Good company to have on your CV.
cons:
Treat the graduates pretty poorly, there is no transparency with them when senior management make business decisions. Lack of support for individuals and treated like 'resources' instead of actual people. No control over your own career and only put in roles where it suits management best, rather than where you actually want to work. Managers make you do a lot of admin work rather than actual valuable roles and also little client contact. Little to no recognition and acknowledgement of your career aspirations. Retention rate after the graduate scheme is terrible, they can't seem to hold on to the good ones.
Advice to Management
Treat graduates or those who have transitioned off the graduate scheme better. Have more transparency with them and also listen to where they actually want to grow their career.

pros:
· Classic tech company amenities: free coffee, snacks, drinks. 
· The majority of coworkers are nice and friendly. I genuinely appreciate some of them and these few were the highlight of my experience. 
· Huge bell curve. Top engineers there are brilliant, but the worst ones are unmotivated and coasting. Average engineer is nothing to sneeze at. 
· If you want to coast, a good place to do it. Seemed like people could wfh whenever. 
· There are opportunities to work hard.
cons:
· Pay is not competitive for the location. 
· Bad apples. While they exist in every workplace, their existence speaks to the company's culture and behavioral hiring bar. Now that I work at a better company with coworkers who don't exhibit any of this behavior, I'm not afraid to talk about my experiences. One of them in particular harasses vulnerable people and says the most grotesque things that have no place in a professional environment. He hides behind his long tenure to get away with it. No one except for my mentor spoke up about it and some of his work friends even encouraged him. I would highly not recommend working here if you are a young woman. 
· Management lacks structure with task assignments and does not keep promises. I worked overtime for a reference and never even received it despite promises from and reminders to my manager. Looking back, I realized I was being exploited by my manager and tech lead to do as much work as possible. 
· Lack of formal structure. Despite being a big company, absolutely no structure for anything except for the bare minimum. There's no way to keep track of tasks.
· Mediocre engineering standards. Not much of a formal code review process and poor code quality.
Advice to Management
Keep your promises and if you want to attract talent, you need to increase compensation.

review_title: The company rewards the people that "play the game", your skills do not matter
pros: Cannot find one, you can learn here how to have your time wasted, how to waste others time, how to work with arrogant/damaged seniors/middle dev/students, join politics afterwards. People come and go, management never changes, it is promoted to higher hierarchy. Current employees are not receiving incentives, always have to deal with the no-employee-retention unwritten rule, no raise, new employees hired. The company rewards the people that "play the game", your skills do not matter.
cons:
Salary way below the average pay for the role, no raise, no technical growth, lots of useless corporate "tasks" , micro-management in weekly bookings, way too many meetings . God forbid you receive a project with a team assigned only on that one project for decades! The arrogance, the waste of time people in management in this company are willing to offer, only to keep an old project where they cannot change the other many years old team it is completely absurd. Project Managers that are always happy to throw another log on the fire when the building is burning, staying in their positions for years, must be changed urgently! Obsolete software, low number of vacation days - working with Germans shows you IBM has such a thing as a personal holiday for employees there, but for Romania overtime is paid only for those few preferred persons
Advice to Management
Hire competent HR, recommendation from employees should be taken into consideration, not only from the one person preferred by the management. Do not hire based on gossip. It is not only unethical but it causes problems along the road and you just add one more thing to the dirty politics existent already. Change people in management positions, chenge the confused senior leadership, but not by promoting them.If non-management employees come and go and the direction is still not moving forward, guess where the change should be made? Motivate your employees, bring better technologies, stop the toxicity and do your job!

pros: Good place to start and develop your early career, some smart and dedicated colleagues, decent pay when you start your career, possibilities to grow until certain point if you know how to network with the right people at the right time.
cons:
Promotion can sometimes take ages even if you deserve it before, at some point the wages are not competitive compared to most of tech companies in Dublin, not a clear career path, benefits very limited, you basically pay for everything except for an inside doctor that is in the office a couple of days a week, and uncertainty around where the company is going that made many employees leave including myself.
Advice to Management
Focus on keeping your young talent by giving them more career possibilities and opportunities to promote. Plenty of them rather go to other IT companies because they don´t have these possibilities in IBM

review_title: Has the best culture, growth opportunity and overwhelming amount of learning
pros:
* Best of it's culture, you're always respected, very inclusive, and always takes it serious when it comes to any degradation of individual or group.
* Enormous growth opportunity. You definitely reap what you sow. Invest your time in learning and picking up new challenges and you will see amazing things with your growth within the organization.
* Overwhelming amount of Learning. There's so much of learning materials (You'd hope that you had all the time in the world to complete those). Coaching and Mentoring comes easy as people are always willing to do it without any disparity.
cons:
* Very process oriented organization but that's understandable as it's a huge matrix organization.
* Change is the only thing that never changes - happens too often at times (You have to keep up with it).
* Organizational changes can affect your employment. (But you're always given the option for internal movements for any available vacancies which fits your profile and experience)
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: IBM is changing but has legacy anchors slowing that change
pros: Truly more world-class minds per capita than most other enterprises I've worked for; they generally keep tenure for this kind of talent. Good but not great benefits.
cons:
Legacy systems, processes, and thinking weigh down the shift from the IBM of old and the AI and Hybrid Cloud company of today.
Advice to Management
Make the hardest change possible as fast as possible: away from extracting value from clients to creating value for clients. Think about creating the best client experience and then work backwards from there so that we orbit our clients instead of our clients orbiting IBM.

DAVE WRIGHT, DESIGN
READ DAVE’S FULL STORY ON MEDIUM

pros:
- There will always be an interesting project to work on with engineers who are genuinely excited to innovate
- Pension is very competitive 
- Life insurance is very comprehensive 
- Decent budget for providing tech for engineers (Latest Macbook Pro, 4k monitors, keyboard, standing desk etc.)
- Moving across departments to work on different areas of the company is fairly easy and accessible
cons:
- Salary is below average for the role
- Deadlines often are infeasible for the amount of work needed to be done
- Moving up in the company is fairly difficult, there is a long lived culture of "do the job for at least a year to prove you can do it, then we'll think about promoting you", which causes a huge backlog of engineers waiting for promotions.

review_title: Great place to work with some "buts
pros: Diversity, flexible hours (unless you work for GBS), plenty of trainings available on internal learning plataform.
cons:
Salary is not great, it's lower when compared to the same function in other areas. Also, IBM seems to have benefits they don't want employees to use. For example, during the pandemic they "made available" chairs and office supplies for employees to take. But to be able to take it, you need to pass for an interview, prove that you really need something, that you can't use something you already have in your house and ask for a bunch of approvals. They made simple things unecessarely complicated.
Advice to Management
IBM needs simplification. To simplify the structure, the processes, the politics, and give employees benefits on a good will - not just to show the benefit exists.

pros:
IBM provides unlimited WFH that is actually good. But do not get over-exicited reading this! Even this can depend on your manager ;)
 Working in b-shifts and c-shifts are less
 Women are provided cabs from 7 pm onwards to reach home safely if you get approval from your project to bear the cost
 IBM provides unlimited sick leaves which no other organization has
 There is no stringent 9 hours work policy. No swipe-in and out policy to record your working hours. Complete your work with no defects and you are good to go :)
 Work life balance is good
cons:
IBM is not recommended if you are joining as a fresher. The opportunity to grow within the organization being a fresher and working at the most lower band is minimal. Exceptions can happen - ‘You are lucky if you get a good lead and manager’
 You don’t get any perks for your hardwork. Poor pay package, almost no onsite for band 6
 The company policies (for hike,onsite,band progression) are not very transparent and no scope to contact your HR. Your only hope is your People Manager. Your future in IBM is in the hands of your manager

Repor

pros: Work Culture, Flexibility, Secure, Stability, Community.
cons:
No new opportunities,
No hikes (even after 5 years of hard work and loyalty),
No HR interaction,
High managerial dependency,
You are just a number.
Advice to Management
Loyal and hard working employees need hikes as well; their salaries should at least reflect the market value of their skill, but in truth - their salaries are less than 60% of their market value. I know many such disappointed people in IBM India.

You cannot go ahead and look out for new opportunities internally no matter what you do. My manager in the last project I was a part of actually said it to the face of his team members - "you won't be released from the project, you can however quit working in the company".

In another incident one of my colleagues actually had to fight with his manager to change the project so that he can add a new skill to his knowledge. He had to go the upper management and include them in this fight of values. Even then, as a final resort, he could only separate from the company in the end, frustratingly!

Trust me when I say this, even after working for 5 years in IBM, I am the least paid employee in my team of 25 members.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

pros:
Benefits were very good, especially for mental health coverage.
Free parking and EV charging
Decent starting salary 
Flexible work schedule
cons:
Toxic work environment with management. 
Organization often “switched gears” in vision, resulting in wasted designs/work. It felt like the product teams had commitment phobia when it came to seeing through project work. 
Managers/ execs would often talk down to subordinates or be very passive aggressive. 
Politics were unbelievable! Lots of strange things happening behind the scenes around promotions and pay raises.
Bonuses are practically non-existent unless you push for a good deal when you are hired. Don’t expect much in terms of salary increase moving forward.
The lab that I worked at is in the middle of Markham… the commute really sucks unless you live nearby.
Advice to Management
If an employee works well and is highly skilled… make sure you offer them reasonable pay increase, promotion opportunities and bonus payouts. 

Please treat folks with respect and dignity. Some managers were very nice, but I was shocked about how many managers/executives were awful and pretentious.

pros:
- My coworkers are pleasant and generally capable.
- Generally rewards excellence
- Lots of free materials and courses to learn from
- Work hours generally fit a standard 9-5, only had a crushing load for a few months of my 3 years here, and it's largely my fault for overestimating my ability
- Good managers invested in my growth and career
- Good base pay
cons:
- I've kind of been left to my own devices since 1 year and 3 months in. I'm happy to take ownership of the product I work on, but I don't feel like my technical skills are up to snuff without having a senior help me learn what I don't know.
- Promotions weren't hard but they aren't easy either, there's only so many positions to go around.
- A decent amount of turnover in the sense of people leaving IBM for something better.
- The directives from upper leadership leave something to be desired.
- It's a big, bloated machine. It works, just not always quickly.
- Good base pay, but no other compensation
