review_title: User Research practice still has a long... painful way to go
pros: There is so much to learn. So many amazing people to learn from. Salary and benefits are ok. IBM is hybrid and flexible work friendly but seriously clinging on to the co-location strategy.
cons:
The User Research practice at IBM still has a long way to go. User Research is still not recognized as its own independent discipline and rather considered a specialty under design. If you are a User Researcher and considering joining IBM. Be prepared to constantly be called a "Designer". Be prepared to not be included in many conversations and decision making efforts because many still don't understand what user research is or how it can help other than concept testing. Be prepared to be told what to do by the design discipline because ux designers and user researchers don't have equal seats at the table... you will not have a easy time. You will not feel fulfilled unless you luck out and have a team that somehow has established a better process than the rest. You will have a difficult time growing your career here as a User Researcher. You will have a very difficult time recruiting participants, you will be micromanaged, ignored, etc.) You will witness UX Designers get promoted and awarded and applauded frequently while you feel stuck... bored.... stressed.... overworked.... fatigued.... unmotivated.....depressed
Advice to Management
Recognize User Research as an essential discipline and provide them with needed resources. Educate product teams about the value of User Research and how/where to engage them.

pros: Flexible with work from home, relatively high pay (but low for big tech), some in demand skills and experiences.
cons:
Limited exposure to work with clients, dysfunctional sales methodology. Product roadmaps were very unstable and often rebranded and shifted products in a way that left clients unsure of what they were buying. Many of the software products are created and not maintained, either from FAQs all the way to functionality issues. Also the company really isn't ready to sell in a cloud based world, there are still a lot of perpetual licenses and the company really struggles with selling usage based products like AWS.
Advice to Management
Stop the crazy HR churn which adversely impacts teams as well as roadmaps. Be more open to making the products easier to use and focusing less on creating opportunities for GBS. Stop forcing solutions that are bespoke just to win GBS revenues when in the long run you jettison software sales for products that are less transformative.

review_title: Not a perfect organization, but will keep you afloat if you're willing to thrive and stay onboard
cons:
ltant in Manila, Manila, Manila
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- Puts a premium on integrity above everything.
- Follows a pay for performance philosophy.
- Encourages and fosters continuous development of its talents.
Cons
- Several managers are ill-equipped to adequately support and motivate their teams. There are those who have no genuine connection with their direct reports, lacking capability to build rapport and sense of belongingness among team members.
- Some leaders are out of touch on what's happening on the ground. At times, strategies don't make sense (example: compelling a broad range of sectors/service lines to be cross-certified in technologies that are irrelevant to the experience and skill sets of the impacted practices).
- Not all centers are created equal: no matter how willing you are to work across borders, there are geos that simply don't work well when put together, especially in high-pressure engagements.
Advice to Management
I hope that regional/global leadership is looking into what the countries are attempting to do, especially "mandatory" certifications. Please do not coerce people into taking certifications for the sake of racking up the numbers against the competitors. "Great" that we're aggressive in building our eminence through these certifications, but please have a sensible, well-thought strategy on who should be required to complete them. We're already stretched thin with our assignments and engagements. Obliging some service lines to be cross-certified in technologies that are irrelevant to the experience and skill sets (also: don't improve our current jobs, expand the pipeline for our practice, and help us progress) is dispiriting enough to make us consider taking our talent elsewhere.

On the other hand, please refine on and enforce a development plan for Manager / Senior Practitioner roles and up. There are very few leaders in our immediate organizational level whom we can aspire to emulate, even fewer who have the finesse (or even domain knowledge) to work with aggressive clients. It's painful to see supposedly senior talents limping their way through client interactions after being shot down for not having domain expertise and the polish to make up for it. Our clients deserve so much better; we IBMers deserve so much better.
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros: I like the old culture better. The people were awesome and more like a family. The old culture carries the tradition of virtues and respect. The hard effort and performances displayed are appreciated. The direction of the company is more directive and transparent. There is a work-life balance if you know how to manage the workloads and expectations.
cons:
Due to a shift in leadership these recent years that caused major re-org, employees were seen as more of just numbers than valuable assets. In addition to the never-ending change of managements and so-called transparent goals, it caused many unclear directions and major turn-overs. Unhappy stressed, and anxious employees are not only struggling to maintain the increasing double or triple workloads but also nervous about their own positions in the company

review_title: Investor in People and lots of innovative technology to work with.
pros: Forward looking company that continuously invests in people to meet the demands of emerging technology. Some exceptional people work at IBM and there is a lot that can be learned from working with people of high calibre. The company regularly innovates, invents and patents new discoveries. Very supportive colleagues and the company really steps up, if there is anything like a family or personal emergency.
cons:
As with all services companys, the hours of work can be long to get projects over the line.
Advice to Management
Help all employee achieve a better work life balance, reduce stress and tell clients that when things go worng, which isn't the fault of IBM, that project timelines will be impacted, rather than making employees work long hours to meet the original end date.

review_title: Wonderful company, awesome culture, a bit bulky
pros: I love IBM. I was in college intern in the summer of 2019 and now I am a full time employee. The culture is kind, hardworking, innovative, and encouraging. We know IBM is not the coolest kid on the block (of tech companies) but we are passionate to help IBM grow because of all the neat work and technologies we have here. What I appreciate most about working at IBM is how understanding the people are. The company really treats us well.
cons:
It is quite oversized and some parts are siloed because it is big. Makes it hard to disrupt the industry.
Advice to Management
Keep treating your employees awesomely and giving them reign to explore, experiment, and thrive.

review_title: Works for some people, not for me
cons:
ltant in Dublin, Dublin
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Allows a lot of freedom for activities outside of work. 
Opportunities to travel within the UK and Europe.
Good trainings run by global team i.e. Communicating with Impact, Leading with Impact.
Cons
Low expectations on employees leads to few interesting pieces of work (in Ireland).
Tendency to 'pidgeon-hole' graduates into roles once they've been trained in something i.e. if you do an SAP project you will be pushed to SAP almost always.
Very few work-benefits - No subsidy for food, not even free tea / coffee in either office (Mulhuddart or Ballsbridge)
Advice to Management
Currently GBS in IBM looks like a great option for a not-very-ambitious person who values family / social life over their career. 
I'm not sure that's what the future of IBM should be.

pros:
For the management really there is no PROS. 
Really unmanaged management.
cons:
Please, dont join IBM if you are ambitious and come from varied skills. Even if you are confident that you can be good, then also the movement and managerial restrictions will exhaust all your efforts. So, please rethink before joining. 

As you may have heard, IBM takes 3-5 years for giving any salary raise and that too depends on your performance. No special bonus. Dont get lured by their business ventures and other things as long as you are working on an individual level.
Advice to Management
Please, for the sake of humanity better yourself. Enough careers have been dusted down because of you management. Unnecessary restrictions have made many employees loose their passion in their job. Even the market reviews say the same if not just my review.

pros: Great place to learn with ample resources to do your job with and explore interests. I found that subject matter experts were generally easy to get in touch with and learn from if proactive about reaching out. There's always something exciting happening somewhere in the company, and offering management has great exposure to much of what goes on. Found IBM's corporate values were generally prevalent across the company. Met many people who became sincere friends outside work.
cons:
Matrixed company felt disjointed and difficult to move around; it seemed like two people could have the same job title and be doing very different things, or be in different parts of the company and have very different experiences. A lot of bureaucracy at times, and the work could be a grind. 

If you love engineering and dev/ops, you'll probably be happier here than if you love B2C work. When IBM gets it right, they really get it right, but you have to know up front that IBM isn't the right place for everyone.

pros:

review_title: A good place to start for fresh graduates
pros:
- Salary is okay but definitely good for a first job
- 13th month pay
- Benefits
- Colleagues are great and they help a lot in decreasing stress
- Gives a lot of experience in interacting and communicating with all types of people from all over the world
- Develops your communication and professional skills
- Reimbursements for transportation and work related purchases
cons:
- Typical call center work
- Stressful job
- Don't expect to take your lunch and breaks on time
- A lot of stats and milestones that you need to reach
- More work but no increase in pay
- Management lacks integrity in some matters and prone to change their minds on certain decisions
- Transportation reimbursement is denied even if former employee worked during said dates
- Management keeps leveraging agents to do different types of work instead of focusing on the agents already assigned to that specific task which contributes to the piling up of workload
- Too open and friendly culture, which is good actually, but sometimes breaks the line between professionalism and a lack of decorum.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: IBM India is a good place to work if you are consistent.
pros:
Overall healthy environment. Focus on your work, keep publishing articles, papers, assets... keep yourself visible. So many opportunities to learn and grow.

"Great place to work for women" (in quotes...). Policies and culture are very sensitive towards women's safety.
cons:
Few points:
* Very easy to get in the comfort zone. There are fix formulas to survive in IBM, and they keep changing with time. Complete projects with 'n' rating, publish 'n' articles/assets/papers and you are good till next KRA. On the face, this looks fair, but this is manipulated with 'visibility'. Visibility in IBM is like SEO (search engine optimization). And there are non-organic ways to increase your visibility. I'm not suggesting that this is the fault of IBM, this is just humans being human (or desis). 

* Growth is slow in general unless you have great visibility. 

* Organization has no face. You can work in IBM for years and years and never meet your manager, or somebody from accounts, HR, etc. . Everything happens via systems, which work like a well-oiled machine. But without faces it gets uninspiring. Nobody is there to push you to grow, to learn further, to actually innovate. So if you are not self-driven... you find yourself either in your comfort zone or in survival mode.

So find a mentor and few close friends near your cubicle (or in your Zoom call list), regardless of their role, competency, or color (of the project... Green/Yellow/Red, etc. )
Advice to Management
Find opportunities to talk and inspire your employees.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

Find opportunities to talk and inspire your employees.

- Equal pay organization 
- Great opportunity to learn different skills and it supports certifications each quarter 
- Allows 360 degree feedback and really listens to the employee feedback 
- Top management always communicates with the company strategies and keeps all informed 
- Robust system of grievance redressal.
cons:
- Appraisal system is not great
- Salary given compared to the markets very less. 
- Not enough opportunities to move to latest technologies or grow in different roles.
Advice to Management
- work on identifying areas where the resources are interested to grow and provide opportunities

review_title: Big machine, learning opportunities, bureaucracy and visibility more important than actual performance
pros:
Access to learning resources.
Generally a good environment and not too pressurised.
Flexibility around personal and family matters.
Security.
Good pension and health insurance.
cons:
Visibility is the most important thing, but put your head down and perform is not rewarded in the long run.
Quite hierarchical organisation, your manager is in charge of much of your destiny. Skipping management levels is possible, but not appreciated.
Lack of transparency at the managerial level regarding organisational matters, projects etc.
Lots of red tape, difficult to get things done.
Advice to Management
Look more after your employees, rather than the people above you.

pros:
As a current IBM employee, it depresses me sometimes to think back on my past employers and just how many of those workplaces were managed by "man/woman-children" who -- more often than not -- let emotion and personal biases control the daily decisions they make. At those places, *genuinely* good ideas by lower-level staff would be ignored 100% of the time if the idea somehow threatens the manager’s brittle ego or even *slightly* increases their workload. These were Tywin Lannister-wannabes I’m talking about – that view their employees as a group of undisciplined children requiring constant supervision, restricting the tiniest of freedoms and establishing authority by reprimanding non-offenses. For these "control-gestapos", managing isn't the goal. Coasting through a life of upper-middle class perks and authority (in title only) is their only motivation. They inhibit any and all culture and creativity from a work environment and drain the lifeforce out of their staff. Sirius Black would never have escaped if Azkaban had a swarm of micromanagers flying around in black hoods. I will be honest with you here… I consider each and every single one of these Putin-sympathizing, workplace-tyrants out there actively defiling our country’s workplaces to be my eternal arch-rivals. 

I guess what I’m trying to say here is IBM does a good job of saying “do this thing by the end of the month” and leaving you alone.
cons:
You will be constantly losing roles to other IBM-employees who are more qualified because their CV shows they previously worked in a similar role.

review_title: Fantastic place to work, but be ready to see a lot of changes
pros:
Lots of learning resources.
Great culture for constant self improvement.
IBMers really help other IBMers succeed.
cons:
Layoffs are more frequent than you would like them to be. Valuable peers will be let go, then you will see a new team get created and you wonder why they could not just reassign your peers to the new team.
In many sites, promotions can take forever. To get promoted, you better be ready to look at a different company.
If you stay there long enough, you may end up with a mindset that everything is better at IBM, limiting your chances to move out quickly if you get laid off.

Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Like any entry level consulting job, you're surrounded by other bright people.

pros: Pay was okay but only due to TUPE
cons:
TUPE'd in then told 90% of staff roles would be Offshored over 3 years
Advice to Management
You can't force staff to undertake higher graded roles for the same salary. You can't expect staff to joyfully work at 110% when you openly Offshore every GTS UK role going. You expect commitment and glowing Checkpoint feedback but offer no pay rise (or <1%) and no bonus so basically no incentive.
Management had no interest in what I did prior to TUPE. Everything just seemed to rotate around ensuring Monthly Pay Dates were met by Customer. Customer satisfaction was subsequently less important that ensuring IBM had been paid.
Plus side was I (personally) was left to get on with my Projects and you could work from home relatively freely.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

pros:
Flexibility - Work from home / remote
Online training possibilities (not well advertised internally) with UDEMY and Safari Books
Benefits are OK - Pension / Holiday / Laptop
Good range of customers
cons:
Almost impossible to get bonus based on GDP. 
Payrises are few and far between - Pretty much the only way to get one is to get a job offer else where
Promotions are such hard work that they're not worth bothering with
Band 8+ don't get paid over time and only get TOIL, which you struggle to take
Multiple redundancy programmes every year - never sure if you're going to keep your job from one year to the next
Constantly having to justify your performance which is just a tick in the box exercise for management. Even if you have a brilliant year and smash all targets, you get nothing for it.
Advice to Management
Start putting your employees first instead of the shareholders.

review_title: Great Brand, Great Company, Great People
pros:
-Intelligent, focused, legacy tech company. 
-Kind, gracious, supportive environment where learning is encouraged
-Remote work opportunities (as of 5/12/21)
cons:
-Marketing division group think
-Too many layers of middle and upper management (top heavy)
-Not enough opportunities for advancement
Advice to Management
-Streamline upper level management, especially in marketing
-Again encourage the IBM philosophy of "Wild Ducks" instead of group think patterns- individualistic, out-of-the-box creativity
-Create solid rewards and opportunities for those who overachieve

cons:
ltant in Bangalore
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
1. Learn New Technology
2. Brand with Oldest Tenure 
3. Allowances
4. Cab Facility

Cons
1. Hike is less 5 to 10 % max every year

Advice to Management
The only advice I joined at 2.9 P.A and after 4.5 Years I am not equal to 4 Lacs and there is no hope to reach some good package in future which definitely make person seek something good outside .
Hope so the company will work on the cons.
Thanks rest is Excellent in IBM

pros: Good learning opportunity , access to certifications and encouragement for learning.
cons:
No hikes at all ,work pressure, pathetic managers , no growth you will end up working for years in the same role . this company is run by managers and HRs don't have a clue. nothing is transparent , so much work pressure that you might have mental illness. there is nothing encouraging to work more. I spent 2.5 years and got 400rs hike after working with all my efforts . the CEO and management are only worried about there performance in wall street and are not sure about anything that happens internally.
Advice to Management
Please have a HR team who can monitor on managers who are partial towards employees ,Please be transparent about how an employee can improve his financial benefits. no one deserves a 400 INR hike even after working for 2.5 years in the same firm and being a loyal employee. every account managers have their own rules and make and play the act accordingly . the whole system should be fair for every employee .

review_title: Hopefully doing a big turnaround... heading in the right direction!
pros:
Recent leadership changes (last year) are really prioritising growth.
Very accomodating and flexible place to work.
Amazingly passionate technical teams who LOVE the technologies they work with.
cons:
1. Bureaucracy, bureaucracy, bureaucracy! Totallly siloed business restricts the innovation that teams can actually perform. Business processes are so opaque and varied across business units and even manager to manager.
2. Slow to act on climate goals - employees branded "idealists" for asking climate-related questions in CEO ask-me-anythings.
3. Had to essentially get another job offer on the table to get an overdue promotion. Requests were ignored despite having ~8 senior employee support statements. Ended up happening in the middle of a bad quarter, which gave leadership the appearance of being shocked and desperate. 
4. So many people! IBM has one of the biggest workforces in the world - and isn't moving fast as a result. Definitely adopted Agile (in some teams) but not Lean!
5. Often hard to trace through from corporate strategy to your functional role... but this is getting better with concerted effort from leadership sharing strategy.
6. Very few opportunities for progression in the UK in comparison to the rest of the world - and no opportunity to relocate.
Advice to Management
Keep heading in the same transformational direction. Be careful not to go on a hiring spree after the recent RAs. Keep bing pretty ruthless - more needs to be cut to turn the company around and make it profitable. Employees are ready to work in a growing environment - you need to give them that, not just tell them how to behave.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Like a big heavy machine, like a bird with wings clipped
pros: Follows the internal rulebook in conducting business. For example, one year a portion of my team received a significant portion of additional pay due to an adjustment based on working hours. It appears to me that IBM Payroll self corrected this without employees prompting the company for it. This shows IBM internal business is conducted strictly based on the written policies.
cons:
Company is encumbered by unnecessary processes, not nimble. Top down managerial approach. Company made acquisitions but does not know how to keep the vigor of the acquired entity alive, instead, shows down the energy by IBM's old fashioned culture and our sector was eventually divested from IBM so I say IBM need to think through their acquisition strategy. If you have multiple acquisitions that did not work out, it seems to question the business judgment of the leadership.

pros: Some wonderful co-workers and very smart people.
cons:
This company is constantly playing catch up with their products. They are trying to stay relevant by buying other products which do not provide for seamless integration. Even legacy products are lagging compared to newer company’s offerings. The senior management has no care about creating relationships with their clients. It’s about the sale, regardless of what the customer needs or wants. Senior management is all about the metrics of how many calls or opportunities you create - valid or not. It’s a toxic environment for sales people. Commissions are being reduced annually. IBM thinks the future is fresh from college hires, knowledge and business savvy be damned. They want sheeple, mot people with brains or a conscience. Morale is pretty bad amongst lots of organizations.

review_title: Coming up on one year as a Sr UXD contractor
pros: My work is purposeful and interesting including feature design, product redesign and integrations. While brought on to do UXD my role is 50% User Research—fortunately I have the education and experience to design and conduct valid user research. Good work culture: I love working with my team of engineers
cons:
IBM keeps dedicated proven performers on contract because "they don't have the budget" ...Paying significantly below market rates, there is no incentive to stay even when I'm exceeding expectations, love the focus of my work and my team is a great fit. My division is led by engineers including my manager and skip level manager. There is no design at the leadership table and while there is an expressed value placed on UXD I have to doubly work to help management understand design principals, trust design decisions and realize (this is big) what constitutes valid user research / design research.
Advice to Management
Look around at the competition; Leading with human centered design and research is transformative for driving innovation and business goals: so invite us to the table! Keeping high level contributors in contractor limbo paying well below market rates....isn't equal to your awesome culture and brand.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Good Company; Fair Benefits; Mediocre Pay and Slow Raises; Poor 401k matching
pros: Fair Benefits; Good Mgmt Team; Able to work from home during pandemic. Supportive of family issues. Good place for folks who are getting started in the business. I've staying over 3 years because of work/life flexibility, but am considering moving on due to low salery (<$55k after 3 years!!).
cons:
Client Innovation Center, CIC is a sub-department of Global Business Services, GBS: takes two full years for 401k matching and that does not happen on a bi-weekly basis but only occurs in a lump sum at end of year if you complete the full year.
Advice to Management
Do away with the CIC (Division 1P) and make everyone a Division 16 employee with the same benefits as the real IBM.

review_title: Multiple careers in one great company
pros: Socially responsible, learning and skills-based culture, strongly focused on diversity and inclusion, competitive pay for top performers, work with really smart people creating innovative cool technology. Access to a massive amount of free training. You can move between teams, to different sites (even globally), and through different professions. Great chance to have multiple careers all in one great company.
cons:
After years of transforming to Cloud and AI, business results are just showing signs of positivity, which means raises and bonuses will take a couple more years to improve. But potential is high.
Advice to Management
Continue to reward top performers and increase internal mobility so employees have even more opportunities to chart their own course.

location: San Jose, San Jose, San Jose
pros:
Working at IBM was good. The problem was the client we provided services. 
Good benefits.
cons:
-Working for the TAO (Talent Acquisition Optimization). Last year, IBM and the client made the launch of a new recruitment methodology. These are the things that went terribly wrong: 
*They gave us poor onboarding, months after the office launch.
*There was a huge and constant escalation culture.
*Poor planning of the processes and procedures.
*They changed recruiters to this position (clear demotion) and helpdesk agents too (with no rise in payment, even though they were doing the same as recruiters). 
-Poor (or no) HR involvement in the situation.
-The talent care advisor position is just a call center appointment scheduling position. They sold us the position as a great growing opportunity.
- The majority of the team resigned to look for better opportunities. No one did anything about it. They just let us leave.
Advice to Management
The manager wasn´t able to stand up for the team.

review_title: Either it is a good product or a sad product

if you are working on a good product, you will be busy,
if you are working on a bad product, prep to get downsized, adious, or lucky someone might take you in for your talent

der IaaS as the foundation to future-proof your business. IaaS solutions are designed to be highly scalable and flexible, meaning you can buy additional resources and features you need as your operations expand. Compare this to having to buy more physical hardware and hiring more IT professionals for maintenance as your business grows and you require more storage and servers.
Cons
One good analogy for IaaS is that of a leased car. Say you are in the delivery service and business booms. You don’t need to buy a new delivery vehicle but simply lease another car to keep up with the growing requirements of your business. As demand continuously goes into an upswing, you just lease another vehicle and so on until the economic equation justifies investment in a new car. Buy a new car at the onset then suddenly business drops and you end up with an unwarranted expense.

review_title: If you want to coast and make a decent living this is your company
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Don't really have to do much. Decently strong brand name depending on the group that you are in.
Cons
It can get boring. Most of upper management and leadership is out of touch with younger generations. Essentially a tech company run by their accounting department. High turnover with young people as they are leaving for opportunities that have more responsibility, room for growth, and superior technology and leadership. Also, there seems to be minimal to no bonus incentives for performance; this causes demotivation. Good first job, but not somewhere to stay long if you are highly motivated.
Advice to Management
I don't really know at this point. Should really clean house at the leadership level and have younger people with more technical acumen make the strategically decisions. Too many non-technical people in leadership roles.

review_title: Great place to build a portfolio and contribute to meaningful work
pros: Encouraged to be innovative and expand your skillset (given time during normal work hours). Co-workers are generally positive and help you find your place within a team.
cons:
Policies, toolsets, and procedures change faster than teams can adapt - and a lot of really good tools and ideas are quickly tossed aside before they really reach efficiency.

There is a lot of resistance to change from the veterans (both in age and experience) even if the changes will save them time and frustrations. But given the above con - you quickly see their point of view.
Advice to Management
We realize IBM makes a good share of profits by being a patent hoarder - and thats nothing new. But it would be great if we could stop putting promotions, raises, and recognitions behind arbitrary pattent counts - most of which contribute nothing to the world, let alone a chance to actually be used.

review_title: Well compensated but overweight on personal responsibility
pros:
IBM is a historic company and trying to turn a new leaf with a younger workforce and recent acquisitions/divestitures. The overwhelming majority of managers use the "as long as you get your work done, we don't care how you spend your time" guiding principle. This flexibility has been a lifesaver during the pandemic, where working from home has been anything but a walk in the park.
The compensation appears to be above market and I feel appreciated for my work. The benefits package is a bit underwhelming but made up for in base salary.
cons:
A company this large can be hard to navigate. We live and work entirely in TLA's (three letter acronyms) and knowing them all is a point of pride for some. Getting acclimated takes time and requires individual effort to break silos between teams who should be more communicative with each other.
IBM places a lot of responsibility on individual contributors to complete projects and often makes last-minute decisions that change the trajectory of our outcomes. If you're not married to your work, you'll be fine.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Great people, interesting work, low loyalty to staff
pros: Fantastic people to work with on very interesting tasks. Large enough for you to choose a career change without company change, weathers country and global recessions well
cons:
Lost it sense of being a large family; Staff no longer feeling proud of working for IBM. Focus of the board is fully on shareholder returns and not on staff; despite the fact the largest asset IBM has is the experience and passion of its staff. Employees essentially have become the equivalent of worker drones who are not developed or brought on unless have the right longstanding personal network with a sponsor, though with the unwritten 2 year role cycle any sponsor can quickly disappear
Advice to Management
Look to how staff were managed and supported in the early 2000's. there was a sense of belonging to something staff could be proud of and dedicate their working passions. This you have lost at the expense of chasing stakeholder returns often forgoing salary increases despite giving big share dividends

pros:
1. Work culture is good (subject to job roles)
2. Leave policy is the best in industry
3. Some Leadership is real, especially the HQ
4. LGBTQ+ inclusion
5. Work from home existed even before COVID (IBM, I am sure didnt have a problem adjusting to WFH during COVID)
cons:
1. Poor, if not poorest, in pay/compensation which sadly constitutes the major decision for joining an Organization or not. (Don't be gullible in think 'compensation' isn't primary factor - it should be everyone's decision making factor.)
2. Manager centric Management (so if your immediate Manager is horrible then whole positive gone out of window)
3. Some of the tools IBM use are a drag (though on positive note they also bring latest apps into fold but only on early adopter based & not applicable to all)
4. Some BUs are very toxic like Mainframe/Console Operations
5. Don't join roles below Band 6 - to Management Employees literally don't exist as can be witnessed in their programs & initiatives for Employees
Advice to Management
1. Fix your COMPENSATION package & subsequent BAND increments. This is where IBM lost many gems to competitors. Right from its start. 
2. Get uniformity in open & safe (from unhealthy stress & pressure) work culture across the job roles. Check your attrition records of BUs to see which one are performing poor. Employees haven't left because only "money" but because of Managerial attitude on ground. 
3. Jobs below Band 6 is where some of your important work is performed. Recognize them and help them grow. Concentrate on increments there than at & above Band 6.
4 people found this review helpful

pros: Colleagues and the flexibility to learn new skills
cons:
They have a performance table that you have to meet. However, if you are running at say 94% efficient throughout the year, just before you go for your annual review mysteriously your efficiency drops below the threshold... This is a way that they keep you working extra hours for free. It's not uncommon to be working at 10pm to right a report that no one will ever look at. Also on your pension contributions it's supposed to be say employee pays 4% and employer tops up with 8% etc... Not true, you as the employee pays the full 12%, the pension structure is cleverly set up. If you ever work there, check your payslip ASAP.
Advice to Management
Non! As most of the management are content with the current format as it helps them and not the lower staff. A dog eat dog environment.

review_title: Design at IBM is fast, but IBM is slow
pros: The people who work in the design org at IBM are very supportive, whether it's a fellow teammate or a manager. I feel like I can ask anyone a question and get what I need to do well. The design studio is a very collaborative and fun environment.
cons:
Design at IBM is quite young. As a result, not all of the teams at the company really know what to do with designers. We try to advocate for being involved in the entire product development process, but we're sometimes brought in at the last minute or the time our work takes to do is de-prioritized. Across most of the company, there isn't a very strong process in place, and it's hard for design to truly, seamlessly collaborate with our partners in Dev and Project Management. Which can be frustrating.

review_title: IBM Solutions Delivery, Inc. (Philippines) - Fresh Graduate (2020)
pros:
- Certifications. You can take free certifications here whether it is cloud related or whatnot.
- Learning resources. You have free Udemy and internal IBM Learning Resource.
- Experience working with known companies.
- Free covid-19 vaccination.
- Brand (IBM is a well known company)
cons:
- Salary. This must be the lowest one when compared to its competitors.
- Benefits. Still, not even close to its competitors.
- Higher Management. You know there is a big problem when a fresh graduate felt that there's something wrong.
- Incentives. Non-existent (maybe depends on project)
- Bootcamp. Not that extensive when compared to other companies.
- Known / Big companies are not for fresh graduates. If you have a career path that you want to pursue, never ever apply to big companies who doesn't put what you're going to work on specifically (fullstack development, mobile development, analyst, etc.). Even though you're the top of the class during bootcamp, that doesn't matter at all because they will give you a random role. More than likely, you'll get a support role (ticketing, monitoring, and excel).
- Covid19 response. We passed bootcamp in March 2020, we were deployed in September 2020.

I declined numerous offers between March 2020 to September 2020 with the role that I want because I trusted IBM. I took my internship here (which is miles ahead compared to my current work) and applied here. I didn't expect this from IBM. Its like they didn't even took a glimpse at your resume. Not recommended unless you don't have a career path planned ahead.
3 people found this review helpful
Helpful
Share
Repor

review_title: Great colleagues and experience / poor executive leadership
pros: Great people in the trenches who take pride in the IBMer name. You will not find better colleagues to learn from and collaborate. Flexible remote working capability.
cons:
50 to 60 hour work weeks is often necessary; layoffs are a common yearly occurrence in this company.
Advice to Management
The executive leadership created different atmospheres in each of the business units I worked in during my time at IBM. I would say that my most recent was a toxic approach that flirted with the line of "hostile working environment" definition. I would recommend improving communication skills.

pros: The IBM name still resonates with the older people in the IT market. Usually has good training, basically you can get any virtual training you want.
cons:
There are constant layoffs and unfortunately most talent has left the company. IBM lost the cloud game and is constantly shrinking. Best leaders and employees left to work at new generation companies. Company strategy doesn't make sense.

Salaries and benefits are low in comparison to competitors. Promotion is very hard. Salary raises are usually below inflation levels. Benefits have diminished over the years, for example, the BES contribution is laughable.

The company car plan is outrageous, even if your job requires daily use of a company car, IBM charges you up to 2500TL monthly on the rental car. No proper gas or OGS plan, you basically need to pay them and then get reimbursed.

It feels like you constantly need to fund the company, just like the car, there are a lot of things you need to pay out of your own pocket. For example, when I left, lunch allowance was 15TL/day, which is ridiculously low.
Advice to Management
Focus on customer satisfaction and employee engagement.

review_title: Great place to start your career, however management plays a large role in your overall happiness
pros: If you luck out with a good management chain then I can see why folks stay in this role for their entire career, but it's unlikely. You can create your own schedule so work-life balance is super flexible as long as your closing deals. I like how we are market segmented, so I only work with customers in a particular industry. Great for providing similar market use cases between customers. Travel was abundant prior to COVID which made the job worth it.
cons:
Number driven, Executives are not supportive, not great culture. I feel alone a lot when it comes to getting help or support from a management level.
Advice to Management
Have your best interest in your employees overall career, especially younger sellers. Make it a priority to understand employees career interests rather than just making sure they hit their number and stay put forever. Be active in providing band raises so sellers feel they're progressing rather than digressing. Make employees feel more valued with encouragement and recognition. Filter out the pressure to perform from Executive leadership so sellers can focus on their job.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

Repor

pros:
- Benefits are good - health insurance and family leave is some of the best I've come across in the US
- Exposure to technology and projects that have a lot of real-life use cases and global impact
- The majority of the people at the ground level were some of the smartest, most interesting, passionate and enjoyable people to work with
- Lots of opportunities and resources for self-driven learning
cons:
- Compensation was VERY low compared to market and then didn't increase much over the years, regardless of performance (negotiate well when you first come in, because it pay won't move much once you're here unless you have a manager who is really willing to go to bat for you)
- Everybody in the org was massively overworked - most people were doing a team's worth of work and we were constantly told there was no budget to expand resource, yet every little project was a priority; flexibility was good (though this varied from team to team) but work-life balance was non-existent
- No job security - layoffs happened en masse across the company and always loomed
- Lots of interoffice politics and HR drama played more of a role in career progression than skill or accomplishment which led to people running teams or holding roles they were unqualified for
- No stability within the org - new VPs and figureheads were constantly cycling through on a yearly basis - each with different priorities and direction - and constantly rearranging teams which led to not a lot getting accomplished on a long-term basis
- Career development was all over the place from manager to manager - though in the past couple of years there was a big push for more internal movement, it wasn't implemented consistently across the board; a lot of managers were too overwhelmed with their own tasks to spend much time really managing and developing employees
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Best company I've worked for, has its challenges, but overall good
pros:
* Smart people & experts on every subject, internationally and in the US 
* Flexible work/ life balance 
* Interesting projects
cons:
* Reorganization and employee churn can slow or derail projects 
* Communication from senior management can be weak 
* Employee layoffs at unexpected times for unexpected team members
* Inclusive culture
Advice to Management
* Communicate more about the how and why of strategic decisions, including layoffs and product decisions 
* Hold managers accountable for failed projects, do retrospectives 
* Comp & benefits are good but I've been offered more, high for the industry but middle for the top firms

review_title: Be wary of a company that is not growing but shrinking year over year
pros: Very few, IBM has great technology but unfortunately cannot effectively sell it to customers. No sense of urgency to do so either. The company moves slow, painfully so. Most people join excited and then the company sucks that enthusiasm right out of them with a paralyzing approach to decision making. I am in the executive band and will resign shortly now that they market has picked up. I need to get my mojo back and the thought of leaving is helping me do that.
cons:
Compensation plans change constantly, sometimes multiple times per year, revolving door for execs, talent is weak and most people are looking for new roles, leadership keeps doing the same thing expecting a different outcome. Strategy is built around cloud but market share of cloud is small while competition is growing like wildfire in cloud. When considering cloud, most companies don't even consider IBM. Cuts run deep and impact minorities the most. IBM has great technology but no ability to understand how to use it effectively in customer environments. Industry experience is so weak. IBM shows up and keeps asking clients what they want, no innovative ideas and cannot scale up business (no desire either) until the competition passes them. Too many examples of this over the years. I regret accepting role with IBM and am hoping for a package (ps. packages for execs are great).
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

ltant in Mumbai
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
- Employee Friendly; lots of emphasis on D&I
- Fertile Grounds for Growth; lateral and vertical
- Opportunity to grow by jumping across portfolios (not rare to find IBMers who have worked a mind-boggling number of positions/job-roles across technologies/competencies)
- Loads of investment in learning/reskilling initiatives
- Robust repository of tools for online collaboration
- Opportunities for job-rotation/stretch assignments
- Global Corporate Social Responsibility Program
- Exposure to global teams since most projects run in matrixed environment
Cons
- Lack of a global "promotion" policy; think "promotion" every FIVE years in some countries
- Poor annual compensation when compared to market standard, regardless of established subject matter expertise
- Negligible annual salary hike (unless you're very high-up in the echelon)
- Incredible disparity in income between those who grow organically and those who are hired from outside
- Not the best appraisal process; the definition of "Met" and "Exceeded" is subjective and changes oft 
- Leadership are an entitled lot (think developing countries)
Advice to Management
- Top talent promotions need to be looked into - it's frustrating to keep someone waiting for FIVE years and more to get promoted. 
- About salaries - would be interesting to publish efforts the company plans to take to provide at least 10% to 15% salary increments. 
- Need to have a robust career framework model that educates employees on skills required to move to the next level.

review_title: Make sure you're progressing your career rather than IBM taking you for what it needs
pros:
- There are great educational programmes in leadership, coaching and technical development
- There are really smart people working in the company.
- When you're working with great people they are the reason you stay.
- In some roles you have the ability to shape the role and try out new things that excite you.
cons:
- Salary is below average for the industry, the only way to get on a good salary is through negotiation at hire and after that through promotion of band.
- Very much the in-boys having the power, locking everyone else out
- Management take a view of people being able to switched from one technology stack to another without any thought given to the skills people have been building in cutting edge areas that are very beneficial to the company
- Senior leaders are not able to stand up and have the difficult conversations and truly transform the company. They are too scared even when all of their team are telling them what needs to be said.
- There are so many times there are elephants in the room scenarios and management don't tackle them. There is a serious lack of leadership
- Management expect employees to have no lives and work crazy hours, time and time again.
- Nothing is being done around mental health and employee well being, employees are just meant to deal with their issues without any help even when it's called for.
 - Executives come out with big initiatives without any care for how it's done, causing their teams so much stress on how to execute. There is no vision.
- There is no long terms planning and trying to see what's coming down the line.
- The company is very bureaucratic making it very difficult to get things done.
- It's very difficult to make big changes, there is push back at every turn.
- It's difficult to have the autonomy to drive things forward,
Advice to Management
A true vision is needed. Blindly following a leader is not the way forward, instead people need to be able to build their careers and skills so that they become the best in the field. At the moment with crazy deadline after crazy deadline you're burning people out all being led by Arvind. Crazy deadlines come with many costs, some of which are burning your people and not being able to truly transform the company as you're not building towards a big picture. You have management that are afraid to say the truth, so as messages of what's happening on the ground go up through the management chain they get watered down at each level, so that everything appears to be rosy in the garden. This is creating a toxic culture that has fear at the heart of it.

review_title: Fixing the door whilst the house is burning
pros: Base Pay is not bad though bonus scheme is farce. Nice enough colleagues. Training system is very good, but when you actually seek resource to go and win some business its not available and the process is dire.
cons:
Leadership have clearly lost the plot, obsessed with trying to push Hybrid Cloud when the horse has bolted and already several valleys away with hyperscale providers. Internal process is shocking using lotus notes and Atlas, having to use a password t log in repeatedly to the same applications. Internal sales process is painful and the admin cost to get any sale out of the door is a joke. Not prepared to take people of fee earning work to develop decent bids so you end up with a bench of staff not skilled in the areas you actually need, so you lose the bid. No competitive targets being hit because of this as the A Team is never available and at best you get the C or D team. Management obsess about the current QTR whilst walking towards a cliff edge as no new work being won, But most don't care as will move on promotion or retire with bonus from core work. More obsessed with measuring diversity than addressing the real problems that need real investment like decent CRM and basic email system that works.
Advice to Management
Sort out the basic tools, they are a mess, qualification and release process is a also appalling and not adding any value. Resourcing model utterly broken and frustrating leading to good people leaving, putting 2nd rate teams on bids does not result in winning bids.

review_title: Use to be great but the Dublin office is full of toxic people.
pros: Lots to learn, many smart and interesting people.
cons:
Toxic people, under no circumstances tell anyone anything personal including if you suffer with your mental health, as it will impact your career path. A gossip pit. Everyone out for themselves even though your part of a so called team. Poor management leads to bad moral. Most are numbers people and not people's people. A place where you can never switch off or be left alone by management if you fall ill. Massive culture shift within the centre and not for the best. They tip toe around with band increases and it's few and far between. 9 years there and I didn't get 1. Nothing exciting comes from the company anymore. It's lost it's spark. Avoid!
Advice to Management
Stop being yes people. If you look after your staff the numbers will come. Treat people with respect regardless of their mental wellness. Support and listen instead of blame and intimidation. You need people skills so do a course. It will benefit you and everyone around you. If there is a cry for help don't ignore it, embrace it and be the person IBM have hired you to be and finally stop trying to be everyone's fake friend, learn to listen.
1 person found this review helpful

review_title: Not the company it used to be :(
pros: Working hours can be flexible since a lot is done remotely (but you will work A LOT of hours). Access to a lot of quality on-line education (if you have time to do it after you finish working A LOT of hours).
cons:
Not enough focus on giving people time for career development. Aggressive (sometimes unreasonable) schedules/deadlines for projects. Constant reorganizing of teams and resource actions (lay-offs) leaves many teams understaffed and lacking skills for achieving success. Employees are no longer treated with respect from upper management. Team reorganization and technical decisions are make without consulting the people below actually doing the work in many cases. Most jobs are going to the "low cost geos" like India for example. You may benefit from working in IBM for a while, but long term, be prepared to burn out.
Advice to Management
Please treat employees with more respect. Communicate and get input from people at all levels when making decisions. For the greater good of IBM and individuals, invest in your people by allowing time for training (they are not just "bodies" to throw at various projects as you like to call them).
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Good company to get good experience, but not worth staying long term
pros:
- IBM is a huge company, and has many types of positions in the field of software engineering. It's not too hard to find a team/position to which your skills or you goals align.
- There are lots of smart people there, so you can learn a lot from others
- The IBM name looks good on your resume, for when you want to apply to other companies after working here :)
cons:
- Pay is average in the industry, and not very negotiable
- Hard to move up in the company, too much bureaucracy and politics amongst team members
- Some colleagues I've met are real jerks, and IBM doesn't do much to ensure that workers treat each other well

pros:
I have been working with IBM for almost a decade and I have thoroughly enjoyed the breadth and depth of opportunities that I have been presented with, as well as the challenges I was asked to address on a daily basis, whether this was a difficult problem to solve or coordinating and working with people to drive initiatives and bring them to completion.

I have met people from all walks of life, made good friends and had the chance to see the world by means of international collaborations within the company and outside of it. The nature of my work also allowed me to explore and develop new technologies. I have worked across multiple domains from emergency management, healthcare, to financial services, and this allowed me to grow as professional significantly.

The things that I value the most in my current job are the people I work with, the problems I am asked to solve, and the trust that my peers put in me when I comes to working together.
cons:
Being a big company, IBM may be sometimes difficult to navigate and not as agile as a startup may be. Employee, especially new ones, may be easily feel lost.

pros:
- great work life balance
- Good base salary
Pros or cons depending on your point of view: 
- very academic environment 
- strong fundamental research focus and not much applied research
- focus on publications and not impact on products
cons:
- It is in constant transformation and transition. There is no stability; teams shuffle and research directions change all the time. 
- Benefits aren’t good. Compared to big tech players very bad.
- the location is quite remote. There is nothing around the campus. 
- the food is meh.
- Most people joined IBM right after college. So they don’t know how other tech companies work. They still work in 80s-90s work style.
Advice to Management
I find the lack of applied research and the constant transformation were the biggest issues with the company. With no concrete and clear goal, the research seemed pointless. But again if you just wanted to do academic research and don’t care about products, it may be good for you.

pros: - A variety of experiences you can have at IBM, largely depends on your management,location , business unit and their budget. This is more of a neutral than a pro.
cons:
- Doesn't really invest in their employees in terms of education
- Very withholding of promotion/increases
-Pay may seem great upfront but won't feel as plentious overtime
- A lot of managers are "gifted gab" .... they talk the talk but not nearly as many walk the walk. I suspect it's because many of them have just been here long enough to get the positions.
-Managers have an issues with upper management demands which they may trickle down to you . Won't really address that they are being spread too thin
Advice to Management
Most people who have joined in the past 5-7 years probably leave within 4 years of their time there. There is no real incentive to stay unless you have dedicated a lot to the company which most people aren't doing anymore in the tech space. There isn't a lot of reason to stay at the company unless the person likes their management and what they're working on and that's more of an individual variable versus the company maintaining their mission as a whole. There isn't even a welcome package for folks who join..you'd be surprised to see how many folks who work here who don't even own a decent t-shirt with the company name or a water bottle. Not saying that this is the solution but is a small demonstration of how small the company does relating to it's employees . I've also seen other companies recruiting former IBM employees to work for them...that says a lot about the retention rates of employees.

pros:
Top Benefits
Alot of smart caring people in field and middle management 
Pretty good pay for the market
Plenty of responsibility
cons:
Bureaucracy Bureaucracy Bureaucracy
Difficult to navigate the myriad of "Federal Government" like policies
A lot of groupthink inertia in the IBM cocoon so change is glacially slow to effect
A lot of overlapping job responsibilities among employees causing conflict
Advice to Management
As IBM's Founder Thomas Watson used to say..."THINK". There is a large disconnect between the reports you read and process and what is actually happening to the field sellers, business partners, and customers that you don't ever hear about. Gotta start shedding the old ways of selling and the archaic systems and policies to quickly become a dominant nimble player in the market again as befits the name and reputation of IBM.

cons:
ltant in Philadelphia, PA

CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Good learning experiences offered if you can network your way into a sector that you are interested in. IF you can find associate partners/partners to care about you then there are a lot of opportunities for growth.
Cons
Bonuses are based on the company performance, not individual performance so you almost never get one (if you do its like 1K). I'm a female and sometimes I felt like others had bigger salaries than me just because they were male or bc of who they know.
Advice to Management
Give bonuses or incentives to work harder/better!! Currently there is no incentive.

ltant in Gurgaon, Haryana, Haryana
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook

- Salaries for lower bands (8,7,6) can lag from market.
- Sometimes questionable decisions.
- Can feel a bit top heavy, younger talent tend not to stick long.
Advice to Management
Invest into younger talent. Attracting them is one thing, but we also need to keep them. it can take more than 10 years to get to a good comfortable salary and many younger talent nowadays do not wait because they can get a higher bump in other companies.
Strategy sometimes vague and not complete. we do not stick to one thing and do not do market research to know what is the next big thing. We play catch up most of the time. Need to invest into real product development and play the long game, not just do what our customers want now and hope it will keep us afloat.

review_title: Used to be a good company, not anymore.
pros: These days about the only pro working for IBM is some of the people in certain areas who still keep the old culture alive.
cons:
The additional employee benefits that IBM used to be renowned for in years gone by have slowly disappeared over time to the point where they are now non-existent.

Virtually everything in recent years revolves around saving as much cost as possible.
The simplest of things such as requiring additional memory for your workstation, or a non standard piece of software are ridiculously hard to get with a stupid amount of justification, approvals and general time wasting needed.

Expect zero or next to zero pay rises even if you're considered an outstanding employee. They almost always find a way to rate your performance down, usually by including the company or line of business financial performance as part of your performance review, or at least using that as a justification.

Telling employees they pay "market rates" when that's absolutely not true in most cases. It's also the reason why they will go to the end of the world to employee an existing internal person for a vacant role with minimal if any increase in pay rather than hiring externally where they are forced to pay "market rates" for new employees.

Some areas are expected to do massive amounts of overtime with claiming that overtime discouraged by management because of the additional costs involved. It used to be accepted that if you had to work on a public holiday or weekend that you were allowed time off in lieu, although a recent policy change now prohibits this.

Constant fear of "RAs" (Resource Actions) aka redundancies under the guise of "restructuring". 

Next to zero ability to gain any training other than the basics needed for your role, and it's sometimes a challenge just to get the basics.

For an IT company IBM internally uses extremely antiquated systems.
Yes folks, IBM still uses applications that were around in the 80s and even a few older than that. Get used to using a 3270 emulator on your PC to access those wonderful mainframe apps that are still alive and somehow kicking in the 21st century!
Advice to Management
The company has lost it's way in recent years and I'm not convinced the current or past CEO really knows what direction to take the company in.

You also need to start looking after your employees better otherwise all the good employees will leave and you'll be left with with a bunch of older folk close to retirement age who are just biding their time and others who can't find work elsewhere.

The constant fear of RAs is really, really hurting employee moral and will take many years to turn around after the RAs cease. Those employee surveys don't always tell the truth because many employees don't believe they're anonymous. It's even got to the point where IBM is now the butt of redundancy jokes at a number of other companies.

Unbearable bureaucracy, changes come in slow, salary upgrades come in slowly, and even when they are negotiated, you might need to wait a few months for a salary bump. Recruitment offers good salaries, but keep in mind that will be your salary for a long time. Also they can even be dishonest when calculating separation payments.

Local managers are overburdened and become slow to response to employee needs.
Check your separation payment spreadsheets, you're underpaying unclaimed vacations!

review_title: Big Company with Big corporate functions and management
pros:
- Everything is a mess in the beginning and without a proper handhold of your friends and peers, you won't even know what is happening.
 - you get time to time new things to explore like certifications and badges and even get rewarded to clear some.
 - A lot of learning material to expand your knowledge with the company's various learning portals, and tie-ups with big online learning platforms
- Everyone is helpful and considered as a peer, we respect our seniors but you call them by name, so as to treat everyone alike and with equal respect.
cons:
- Projects to Graduate hire are random, despite your knowledge and skills.
- Sometimes you get lost if you don't open your eyes and have the appropriate help
- Despite such a big company the salary is low, not a pay-master
Advice to Management
- Ease up the corporate process, and make some unified sites for all the employees, so that the employee doesn't have to remember a ton of sites for each process.
- A internal up-gradation program to upgrade their position and salary can be more prominently implemented.
- hire less and more skillfully people

review_title: IBM is where your career goes to die a slow and meaningless death
pros:
- they pay money in exchange for work
- people are impressed when you say you've worked at IBM
- you have the ability to learn a lot of things and gain exposure to a lot of tech
cons:
- extremely difficult to get a promotion or move laterally within the company unless you're friends with the right people. the internal jobs board is meaningless and broken.
- org is so top heavy that your managers will have no power to make positive changes within the org. the real decision making power lies within the manager of the manager of your manager's manager. Your own manager is just a puppet there to make you feel like your words mean something and serve as a punching bag so that upper management is isolated from the discontent of the lower class.
- IBM will not give meaning salary increases even if your original role is greatly expanded and you are doing the work of 4 other people concurrently. If you are in a lousy division, expect that this will not change.
- IBM has this cult mentality over 'badges', which are obtained via completing small mini courses that do not test you for real skill aptitude. You need to obtain a lot of these in order to gain visibility in IBM. Basically, you need to wear above minimum pieces of flair.
Advice to Management
Get rid of the sycophant middle managers. Listen to your engineers because they are the ones that make your organization useful to others.

Repor

pros:
Not many pros. 
1. Like other service based companies. 
2. Trying to maintain the name and fame in the market. 
3.This company is good for the trainee level, senior level and Not for mid level who needs to switch in between.
4. Some work life balance is there depending on projects and manager.
cons:
1. Bed compensation and growth. May be there will be no hike at all for two three years, no matter how much you give effort, if your PMR is more than 100%.( It is an rating of the same band in the market assessed.) Based on that you are getting paid and there is less chance of renew or audit of PMR rating. So if you don't know how much ctc you will get according to your Band before joining, and if it is more than the PMR rate you will end up with no hike for next couple of years.

2. You will be entertained or pushed to do some side work, contribution or help in other projects but that will not help or will not be considered in your career progression. So don't be happy too much.

3. Less chance of getting promotion. You may get lots of appreciation mail doing good but that is the corporate trap to make you feel good which will not help you at all in your career growth.

4. Sometimes company performance which I saw most of the time is below average will impact your appraisal.

5. Managers in IBM is like termite they don't have much context of the project and latest technologies, market standards but still getting huge package. which indirectly blocking the progression of below levels. Don't have proper attigates to behave. Specially at the time of appraisal. 

6. Notice period is 3 months so before joining need to think twice as time of job change it will be a nightmare. As hr will look for the people to join immediately but they will release candidate after serving full notice period.

7. Check for the project details as you may need to work in local client location.

8. Less onsite opportunity. At least less chance within 3 - 4 years.

9.Mails are circulating each and every day regarding the good developments or profits of company which is nothing but illusion. If employees don't have growth at all then top level management is having problem. Because end results is null.

10. No proper coding standards and work methodology maintain.

11 Not good for career building for mid level developer.
Advice to Management
1. Stop planning so much without a proper appraisal and rating process. 
2. Give proper hike to employes. 
3. Need to audit on managers performance first.

pros:
As long as you're not a IBM GTS employee or a GBS employee like me working in IBM GTS project,everything else looks fine.As a GBS Employee you've a lot of perks like:
1)Bluepoints with which you can buy things.
2)Free Subscription to Udemy(everyone) and Coursera(only if you're part of AI studies)
3)Good corporate structure to curb micro-management.
4)Good work-life balance
 5)As GBS associates have numerous learning oppurtunities,which is quite diffent for a gts employee.
cons:
1)NO clear-cut demarcation that IBM GBS employees working with GTS client (future New co)will continue to be IBM GBS employees and support New Co project.This is not fair for a GBS employee who had to sit for a arduous coding interview only to be(if taken under new co without consent) considered later along with GTS associates,who would have joined with a non-coding background.All the sleepless nights spent on studying ,toiling ,studying numerous frameworks and languages in efforts to bear a good brand name in resume all would be gone in a single minute.It's such a morale pulling act during this bleak covid times.
Advice to Management
Let GBS employees working in GTS projects continue to work under IBM GBS,since we bring to the table a gamut of coding skills garnering higher revenue for the company.Consider this as this spin-off is unrolling.

pros:
- foot in the door with a large corporate tech company; resume booster
- opportunities to learn and get certified
- networking opportunities
- some _really_ good projects, a good project will make you very marketable for future projects due to connections made
- respectable amount of vacation time, benefits
- rapid promotion structure, decent raises (5-12%), sometimes bi-annually
- great peer group
cons:
- management seems very disconnected from market needs/growth
- certifications are pushed from management, however you will rarely get put on a project to utilize what you've learned. They are accolades for management.
- consultant shop; management cares to staff projects, though not necessarily in your best interests
- well underpaid; raises seem great but don't affect much being well under the national market's pay scale for software developers
- confusing management structure that constantly changes
- apprenticeship program is well-done in terms of the learning curriculum but not in experience
- certain development practices are severely undervalued
- no 401k match until 2 years of service
Advice to Management
Take care of your people.

review_title: Felt Like Just A Number But Paid Well
cons:
lting By Degrees Entry Level Consultant in New York, NY
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Great starting salary, fun to start with a big start class, opportunities to work on many projects in first year.
Cons
Feeling like just a number and unable to control the path of your career there. They just place you where they need you and don't take into account your actual interests. Very broad about your role when they hire you (not clear what sector/industry you will be assigned too) and make it impossible to switch.

pros: Inclusive and big on diversity. Training is comprehensive and eminence insisted upon. Pay is good + healthy benefits.
cons:
Only innovative in certain areas, i.e. Smart Cities and Quantum Computing with not a lot of true innovation elsewhere. Transition into IBM is poor, leaving employees floundering in their first 1-2 years. There is a huge amount of institionalised red tape, which makes the company very intra perspective and not externally focused, with a lot of old guard managers, who are equally institualionised and driven only by process and politics. Promotion is based largely on revenue generation, which promotes a lot of incapabilities amongst senior managment that don't have the correct level of EQ for strategy or people management. Your IBM experience will be based on who you report to.

review_title: Stay away if you want a healthy work environment and stay on top of your tech skills
cons:
ltant in Washington, DC
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
There are some interesting projects and nice managers
Cons
Promotion process is not equitable or transparent. If you are POC or a woman, you will be held to a different standard and be expected work harder and prove yourself more. Managers will gaslight you and even manipulate you by dangling the promotion carrot to work longer hours and deliver with little or no resources. And if you are a genuinely hard-working and capable person, you will be expected to clean up after people's mess instead of participating and leading career-building or self-development initiatives. Leave this place before it destroys your soul!

review_title: A poor company to work for
pros: Big name with a long proud history of innovation. Research departments and technical innovation are inspiring and might be able to win big again in the future.
cons:
My experiences have not been good with IBM. This is a company that was once a market leader, but is struggling to make the connection with the changing needs of a digital world. And they are panicking. This results in continuous changing priorities, reorganizations, mass-layoffs, broken processes, frustrated customers, and deceiving managers saying one thing but doing something else.
Some might have a grand time at IBM and be safe from the politics that is going on, but for anyone considering a job in IT I would just say this. You deserve better!

pros:
At engineer / developer level, generally a good company to work for. Interesting set of technologies. The local management / leads in Dublin are sheltering for the more general BS at wider company level.
Good work/life balance, ability to work for home.
cons:
This is a company driven by non-technical exec at the top, and a chain of non-technical managers, which is resulting in a very low technical level compared to competition in the Cloud space. Very different from the likes of Google, Amazon, etc.
The vast majority of senior technical leads (STSMs / DEs) are relatively weak - do not exhibit any real leadership, do not have any specific expertise/technical talent, do not understand what is going on at lower level, and have mastered the exercise of BS / politics to seduce their non-technical exec masters. 
Genuine technical talents typically leave the company before they reach senior level with rare exceptions.
Bunch of clowns running a Cloud like it is an on-prem software from the 90s.

review_title: Decent place to start a career, but not a good place to stay
pros:
- IBM has a very open and accepting culture. Everyone there is really nice and usually easy to work with.
- Good work life balance. Being out of the office for appointments, children's events, mental health, etc. is very well supported and encouraged.
- Some of the projects are cool, and it's rewarding knowing that many people depend on the software you work on.
cons:
- I couldn't tell you how many people there are that do literally nothing and never get fired. It is infuriating feeling like you could do the same and it wouldn't matter.
- Some very talented people work here, but at the same time, many incredibly un-talented people do too which ruins the company's/team's progress.
- The pay isn't competitive. IBM will always lose it's best talent to companies with better pay, benefits, and less red tape.
- Deadlines are a mess. I'm surprised customers continue to use IBM products at times given the outages and issues that occur so frequently at the end of every quarter.
- Designing for the customer gets lost in the complexity of IBM's systems. There are so many features that seem good on paper, but are really hard to use/missing functionality that a customer actually needs.
- No one will advocate for you in your career progression - you must do so yourself.
Advice to Management
- You need to clear house and get rid of a lot of poorly performing employees
- You need to pay competitively or else you will always lose your best talent to other companies.

review_title: Good for Fresher and Best for one who see the retirement
pros:
Job Stability
For Learning, IBM provided lot of sources like Free Udemy Access, Coursera Free Access, Cognitive Classes and So on.
Work pressure depends on Project to Project. I worked on both kind of project. Worked 16 hours a day as well or 8-9 hours day in one project.
cons:
No Growth

So, Their Performance assessment policy is all crap. Managers openly will tell you you wont get hike this year or next year because you already have high package or you should negotiate for better package during Joining.
Lot of pressure on Developers who actually do the job. Manager friendly company. So, if you want the retirement, Then IBM is best.

review_title: People are treated as an expense line; not an asset
pros: *Talented and committed individuals; diverse technology portfolio.
cons:
*People are treated like expense items. Decisions driven by short term financials without regard to mission and technological growth. Raises are minimal and not funded well. Investment in education/learning is almost non-existent. High pressure to deliver and continuously invent; while little means to get needed resources and support. 1st and 2nd line management have little authority while having to execute decisions made in the executive ivory tower. Decisions that continually comprise integrity and ethical practices.
Advice to Management
Address the great pay disparities; address the gender bias rather than covering it up with marketing campaigns that disguise the problem. Focus on a technology strategy rather just the next quarters stock price. Either respect the knowledge of your works and management teams. Replace lip service on diversity, pay transparency and valuing people with actual transparent actions and published data to show improvements.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful
