review_title: Not what it used to be... Keep looking
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Salaries are competitive, office perks are nice when compared to smaller consultancy shops but probably average for a big consultancy. Benefits are average at an international level but rather meager for Canada
Cons
IBM just isn't a bold or innovative company anymore. It is culturally not accepting of the cutting edge and really views itself as a service company that charges a ton for legacy tech to third parties in a bind. High pricing was really hard to justify to clients especially when the company regularly subs senior resources on proposals for largely unskilled and arrogant millenials. A surprising amount of bureaucracy and overhead, and amazingly for a tech company, its own internal IT services are woeful.
Advice to Management
You can only live off past glories associated with the IBM brand for so long. The company needs to walk the talk and that means inventing new things that work and that clients didn't know they needed. Feels like IBM today is roughly 1/3 management/sales, 1/3 admin/support and 1/3 doers that are fresh out of school and couldn't hack it at Deloitte. Not a recipe for success.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

pros:
Many Challenges coming from a diverse, changing and proud environment.
Here you can learn how to make ends meet at a very high scale, interacting with teams in different time zones.
Lot of enthusiasm and everyone treated with the highest respect.
cons:
Lack of organisation, business makes highly impacting decisions with very little technical advice. Agile is followed as a result of implementing ceremonies, rather than genuinely understanding the core principles.
Advice to Management
Embrace true Agile: don't be afraid to start small and expand in small iterations, rather than planning huge projects with tight deadlines. Involve dynamic tech experts in your ideas at an early stage.

review_title: Great Company for new hires - senior executive level cadre to lead & grow
pros: IBM has a strong heritage, lives by value system, +ve culture and gives significant empowerment, support to lead boldly. There is a growth mindset and zero tolerance towards bad behaviour. Evyerone is treated equal and there is no discrimination towards any employee regardless of level, race, gender etc. Nice to see IBM continue to advocate high integrity universally across countries.
cons:
IBM is an ocean and sometimes complex to navigate. For those who are not shy it is easy to get things done. One has to take charge to get stuff done. It does not happen automatically.
Advice to Management
Dont be too conservative. Advertise and share vocally all the good things. Other companies who have no / little values show off as if they are the best. Let everyone see the real IBM values.

ltant
23 Mar 2021 - SAP Basis Consultant in Hyderābād
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
IBM provides unlimited WFH that is actually good. But do not get over-exicited reading this! Even this can depend on your manager ;)
Working in b-shifts and c-shifts are less
Women are provided cabs from 7 pm onwards to reach home safely if you get approval from your project to bear the cost
IBM provides unlimited sick leaves which no other organization has
There is no stringent 9 hours work policy. No swipe-in and out policy to record your working hours. Complete your work with no defects and you are good to go :)
Work life balance is good
Cons
IBM is not recommended if you are joining as a fresher. The opportunity to grow within the organization being a fresher and working at the most lower band is minimal. Exceptions can happen - ‘You are lucky if you get a good lead and manager’
You don’t get any perks for your hardwork. Poor pay package, almost no onsite for band 6
The company policies (for hike,onsite,band progression) are not very transparent and no scope to contact your HR. Your only hope is your People Manager. Your future in IBM is in the hands of your manager.
2 people found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Very well pleased with ability to take part of decision making and action
pros: IBM is 110+ years old. I have worked for organizations which I thought will live forever and today no longer exist. Let that sink in. That survival is dependent on continuous product innovation and go to market. For those that are negative on IBM....have you ever heard of a company with 100%+ satisfaction. It's what you make of it at IBM. I have noticed as of late that executive are reaching out and tapping others for ideas and plans of actions. Collaboration and inclusion ( of ideas) has become a good theme and sustains its "THINK" Moto. Benefits are above par among other and saying this through experience.
cons:
Execution can be slow and this is where you lose patience. Though, they have superior offerings it is sometime overshadowed by its competitors
inferior offering by execution.
Advice to Management
Please continue to tap on the shoulders " to see what they think". There are those with no executive desires but are a fountain of knowledge.

pros: Good Flexibility about working hours, shifts, Work From Home Opportunities at the time of essential requirement. Good support from management during personal, family and health related issues.
cons:
Technical learning opportunities are less and such requests are not entertained. Switching accounts/projects etc are very difficult. Even if you arrange personal self funded training, its not possible to get into your desired roles and responsibilities hence your personal learnings wont be utilized and eventually you forget everything you learnt by yourself. You need to continue to follow the same old orthodox process and policies which are most of them irrelevant in the currently changing environment. You cannot ask Why because that concept is not there there at all. Salary revision/appraisal is not there at all hence you will be continuing getting the same package year after year with no initiative from the management side. Too much frugality in place.
Advice to Management
Implement realistic skill upgradation process and also review fitment of the candidate with the newer requirements with respect to the newly acquired skills. Atleast revise employees salary and compensation once in 3 to 4 years. In case that is not possible to increase it because he/she is already getting the highest salary defined within the band, you should provide feedback about how it can be achieved with skill upgradation, band promotion etc,

pros: IBM is a company that has excellent values. If ethics mean something to you then working for IBM should be at the top of your list. I have been with IBM most of my career and that's for good reason. Strong values and respect for the individual. IBM is so vast that you can really do whatever you want. I started my career in an administrative role, moved to finance then project management and finally pivoted into software development and management. If you have the capability and drive to learn new things then you have a company with endless opportunities. Working conditions are very good and both on premise and remote work are available.
cons:
The company has been struggling to grow revenue the past decade or so which has resulted in resource actions and expense reduction.

Repor

pros: -Remote work during covid pandemic
cons:
-low pay
-high turnover rate
-trained data analyst, but title remains data engineer
-can't take concerns to management, they will assume quitting is your only option
-12 hr days depending on your project
-frequent project hopping
-projects not always geared towards your skills or career
-in office management staff separate themselves from employees
-micro management from certain managers
-raises are low and keep you under average pay until you've reached 4 years
-CICs are located in economically distressed areas for tax breaks. This means although you have a greater number of minorities working, a large chunk of minorities within the greater company are making less than the US average for their job role.
Advice to Management
Treat your team members as equals. Respect goes both ways. If someone has a concern, address it calmly and don't assume we want to quit when we're looking for positive change. Push harder to increase wages rather than increasing the number of new hires. Renegotiate tax breaks and offer higher pay to current employees. Or develop a program that helps current employees transfer to IBM corp. It's not practical to expect employees to stay below average pay when counterparts working the same projects are making double in the same field with the same skills.

review_title: Started out good, but deteriorated as years went by.
pros: Decent brand name for new joiners to establish a name for themselves and their resume. Good training for sales such as global sales school. You get to work with a lot of talented people not only locally, but also regionally and globally to help you close deals with customers and that gives you good understanding of business lessons learned from the different people.
cons:
Constant yearly changes to groups and the products. Spinoffs and layoffs. Difficult to get a band increase unless you have a good manager. They kept changing territory you handle which affects your performance and have to start from scratch often. This decision makes no sense. Lots of internal obstacles to go through to make sure you get the commission you deserve. Politics is always there.
Advice to Management
Hire good leaders, not managers. Streamline operations to make it simple. Ensure that hiring process is better so that new coming managers just don't hire everyone they worked with previously and the culture becomes toxic. We had oracle guys jump in and they gave favouritism to their new hires also from oracle.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: IBM’s employees can take various online courses
cons:
ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
We, IBM’s employees, have access to various online courses (e.g. Your Learning, Udemy) and we can learn whatever subject we want. For instance, some colleagues focus on developing business core skills while others are studying data sciences and AI. We can keep on learning any topic at our own pace besides working. 

These online courses furthermore accelerate our motivation. After completing online courses, we receive certification badges. The badges prove our skills (what we have learnt from the courses) and then encourage us to assign to our desired project. In addition, our learning time and the number of badges also become the areas of annual evaluation. Thus, we will receive rewards if we take curious/interesting courses and develop our skills as much as possible. 

I personally would like to keep learning something new and unfamiliar while working. I appreciate these online learning contents and enjoy taking them.
Cons
The working time depends on the project. 
(I have to work late as my project manager is a night person.)
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Investing in your career to provide all your potential to your self and the Company.
pros:
This company has a big potential, opportunities so a reason to invest our life , being the owner of our future and enabling succeed. I feeling accountable by impacting others with my work and using the very last technology in the markets being also a pioneer in some of strategic areas were the company is investing.

3 Positive Comments: 
- Diversity. With all the meaning. Empathy, Activism and Ally to improve the world we live. 
- Possibilities in the professional career. Millions of curses areas to grow and many Roles to put on practice that learning. 
- People, employees are the best part of this company, we need to continue taking care of them.
5 word minimum
cons:
areas of improvements: 
- Communication between all the different departments in this big family. 
 to know all the products in the portfolio .. and strategy low level by using public OKRs in all departments and provide the opportunity to reuse solutions and avoid duplications and merge goals. 
- Co-create 
- Collocation strategy in the XXI century.
Advice to Management
We need to be able to Co-create : 
 - Do not having duplicate tools doing the same, use all the people working on those to Co-create. And do 1 solution by problem and do the best one in the market. 
 - Award more the achievements done by cross domains and do not have the people fighting for the personal medal of honor, that is an old way of working, and need to be change by changing how the people is recognized. 
 - We have a company with 3 or four speeds, Agile should be everywhere top down ( careful with some of the decisions as collocation is hard today and will be harder in the future when ever we try to find the best skills in locations with low population and when many other companies looking for the same. Increasing cost attrition and just in pro of the creativity .. when the creativity is a table with more than one leg ... You need Skills - Motivation - Experience - and people working together ... then you will innovate and create new ways.

pros: IBM is process driven organisation. As long as the process is adhered to, there is little room for manual intervention. There is great freedom and empowerment. Tonnes of training. Tonnes of global support. There is a team for everything and you are not left alone with any task. Support is always there.
cons:
The process can also be a disadvantage. The employee has to 'self-learn' the nitty gritty details on how they will be measured and compensated so that they will spend their time efficiently.
Advice to Management
New employee onboarding is weak. Only focusses on generic matters but does not focus on individual new hires on the specifics of the role. Employees need to find out on their own and often, the hard way.

cons:
ltant in Pune

CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
I got interviewed at IBM Hinjewadi Pune. Selection process was good and handy. They gave me the job location pune however the job opening was for Bangalore. I got my project and my manager was so supportive to understand my work. I got sick and availed huge sick leaves. Thanks IBM. I also delivered Migration project successfully and got rewarded with Blue Points.
IBM doing great in Cloud Technology however news coming out are not showcasing it. 
IBM has their own products like IBM Watson, IBM Cloud. 
IBM has their own Learning Platform which covers all the trending and legacy tech courses. IF you are a learner then IBM is ur place.
Cons
Finding and seeking help from HR is a task.
Considerable Perks
No Salary Hike
Advice to Management
Should not give a lot priority on client side work culture and time zones. Stand with IBM Employee and do trust on them. They are asset.

review_title: A company dedicated to keeping your skills current and relevant.
pros: IBM builds education and training into your daily job. This means they not only encourage you to stay current, but they back it up by giving you real work hours to complete training. Education is provided via numerous weekly webinars given by Subject Matter Experts across an expansive list of subjects (e.g., Quantum computing to Growing Your Career). Education also is available an endless catalog of up-to-date online curriculum, classes, and funded attendance at IBM and non-IBM Conferences, as well funded classes/curriculum from outside IBM. These classes lead to certifications (also funded) and badges. I've even attended classes at Harvard. IBM is truly the place to grow your skills and your career.
cons:
IBM is pivoting its solutions to support a hybrid multi-cloud strategy. This is good, but at times the transition brings frustrations.

review_title: If the team is right, then its worth the stay
pros: The people I work with were great and professional. Good teammates around the globe. Nice working culture too. Basically, you need to have a good manager that is willing to fight for you and protect you, of course with the condition that you need to give 200% dedication and effort. If not, its a sad place.
cons:
Bad management due to politics. Unrealistic demands and never-ending changes. Possibility of unappreciative response/feedback, regardless of all the effort and successful projects given. Huge gap and poor communication between different platforms/towers/squads. Pay not leverage with the amount of long hours work and effort
Advice to Management
Be decisive, sincere and transparent on the goals and strategies. Understand, do deep dive, analyze thoroughly, and solve the internal issues and gaps. Please do not leap just for the sake of winning the competition, 
Rather than winning a long term success for the entire company, the little achievements that were obtained in these couple of years are more short team, selfish and biased
Be the first to find this review helpful

pros:
High quality and integrity of colleagues

Positive work environment

Potential to support value added initiatives and drive client success, and thereby promote overall job satisfaction

Decent benefits
cons:
Politics and silos can impede career progression

Every year of employment came with the feeling of unease that came from the real or imagined job insecurity driven from a multitude of layoffs - I was the last one remaining from my start group (the ones I kept in touch with) of IBMers; so there's either something very wrong about the hiring process and/or there's something very wrong with how IBM values and grows it's employees

I've seen 100% utilized and well reviewed coworkers laid-off for no reason other than someone(s) had to go even if they were needed and actively contributing, given a corporate directive to trim headcount, etc. revealing the truth that ultimately you are just a number
Advice to Management
Beyond checking process boxes to demonstrate that IBM cares about its employees, actually do care about your employees and don't adversely impact their careers by engaging in arbitrary head count exercises. Maybe for example treat all IBM employees as you treat IBM-Germany employees by incorporating some of the employee protection practices used in that society (or other societies) which place a greater value on their people.
Be the first to find this review helpful

review_title: Great company for recent college grads
pros: Recent college grads treated like golden children. Learning opportunities and wild advancement beyond their skill sets. Young people with minimal skills were trained and promoted
cons:
Experienced people are treated very poorly and have zero job security. A culture of idolized youth over knowledge and skills. If you are beautiful and dress well, you will do well here. If you are middle aged and look over 40, go elsewhere. Worst and most extreme age discrimination practices imaginable. I have never seen or heard of a worse place for people over 40. If even 10% of the staff was over 40. Thus was in what should be a technical and product area.
Advice to Management
If you want the company to succeed, consider listening to talented and knowledgeable staff of all ages. Don't promote only beautiful people who dress well and look good in a meeting.

pros:
- Friendly, smart co-workers
- Still respected across some industries
- Decent place to start your career
cons:
- Low pay relative to other "big tech firms"
- No perks
- Offerings & business model are behind their competitors 
- Lack of effective leadership
- IBM's own consulting arm (Global Business Services) will consistently pitch competitors offerings (SAP) to customers rather than IBM's-that summarizes IBM in a nutshell
Advice to Management
Cut costs, reduce redundancy, and invest those cost savings into the offerings and other cloud offerings. Change the business model from transactional to run-rate and start focusing on the changing needs of your customers rather than your own internal priorities.

review_title: A company in turmoil and decline
pros: Benefits are inexpensive and work life balance is great.
cons:
IBM has a history or creating great products but doesn't feel the urgency to get these to market quickly and doesn't seem to be able to scale anything effectively. It's a place where the mediocre can not only survive, but thrive. IBM lost the cloud war and is shrinking year over year. New people come and go but the strategy doesn't change. they don't listen to clients or care to understand anything about the clients business. It reminds me of when I was a client, they show up and tell you that they do everything then ask you what you want. Nothing has changed.
Advice to Management
Change the strategy. Accept that you lost the cloud war. Use Watson and artificial intelligence as a differentiator before the competition beats you in this space as well.

review_title: Nice staff, very institutional/corporate leadership, overall dated/declining feeling.
pros:
Friendly, helpful staff.
Very accommodating culture. For example transgender, disabled people welcomed and accommodated as far as I could see.
Despite the technology weaknesses, it is still a "big tech" company and does make use of modern technologies / practices, open source, large scale projects etc. although it rarely pioneers them itself.
Room to progress and if you want a reasonably stable career with a solid foundation it offers that.
cons:
Bad salary compared to other big tech.
Aging, technical debt heavy technology.
Seeming lack of investment/vision/drive to properly take on the large problems their technology purports to address.
"It's a career" rather than "rapid progress" feel.
Corporate in many ways.
Always trying to "adopt" and catch up. Rarely hear of new breakthroughs coming from inside like other big tech (there are a few exceptions).
Advice to Management
The current culture is very entrenched which will make any change difficult. Many products could use starting from scratch. The company has a lot of very lucrative long term relationships, which unfortunately causes a lot of problems. It is scared of jeopardising and cannibalising current products with innovative ones. The company also does not know how to target small businesses. Unfortunately, even if you refuse to risk losing customer revenue by launching better offerings, you can't protect them from competitors. The quarter-by-quarter no-risk no-vision attitude (which has its place) just can't survive forever in tech, which is why we are seeing revenue constantly being nibbled away as the cash cows are gradually getting wiser. Despite some weak engineers there are a lot of good technical staff. If you hired in some superstar leaders with true demonstrated vision, proper freedom and incentives to build major products, and some great modern engineers to build cores for new teams, I am sure current staff would get behind them gladly.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful
Share

review_title: Great people, broad opportunities, good benefits, fair pay
pros: I work with some fantastic people. The benefits are pretty good. IBM has worked hard to improve their IT systems we use, implementing more best-of-breed systems rather than building their own stuff (such as HR systems).
cons:
They still use Notes/Domino for email. They too often keep and even promote bad management. Sweeping resource actions result in good people getting let go while poor performers can remain. Almost yearly sales org restructures result in too much churn.
Advice to Management
Kill Notes. Kill the yearly sales re-orgs. Prune bad management, don’t just move them to different orgs.

review_title: Good place to get your feet wet in the tech world
pros:
- IBMers are known for being genuine, nice people. I haven't experienced cattiness, aggression, or any other negative interactions.
- Brand recognition is high--having the name on your resume is good even if the company isn't as prolific as it once was
- There's a big emphasis on professional development with endless resources
- Excellent work/life balance--I rarely work past 5 PM
- Big budgets to try out different marketing efforts
- Working with brilliant, well-educated, respected SMEs is both humbling and exciting
cons:
- IBM is an enormous legacy tech company governed by bean counters, compliance officers, legal teams, and others who minimize our risk. It can be over-bearing at times. Processes always change, and usually not for the better.
- Lack of junior support on most teams. You'll have director-level and lead-level employees stretched thin because they're still doing the same responsibilities even after they're promoted
- Some department execs are lifers (20+ years) which is good and bad. They know the inner machinations, but also tend to be less risk averse or have limited understanding of how marketing happens outside our company
.- We are using email software older than I am and have no plans to migrate off the platform anytime soon.
- IBM has an uncertain future. While other tech companies are booming we're reducing in size. How is that possible?
Advice to Management
Younger, vibrant, risk-taking leadership would be a welcome change. IBM lifers "don't know what they don't know"

review_title: Lagging behind other Big Tech firms in multiple ways & dimensions
pros:
— Decent benefits 
— Good diversity
— Nice campus (Hursley, UK)
cons:
— A lot of red-tape and bureaucracy.

— Very few internal opportunities for growth. Moving teams is virtually impossible, which means there is very little talent reshuffling. Most of the graduates leave the moment their graduate scheme is over, which means that IBM loses its best talent (judging from how difficult it is to get the role), and loses the 2 year investment. How's that logical to anyone in senior management baffles everyone around. 

— Moves very slowly and has incredible difficulties keeping up with Amazon and Microsoft. The burden of legacy outweighs the benefits of a 100+ years long experience.

— Looking from inside, I would definitely not bet any money on the long-term growth of the company. In fact, I would short the stock. Warren Buffett seems to agree.

— Too slow to innovate, too slow to fire, too slow to adapt. Simply, too slow.

— Amazon's valuation is 15th times higher (as of February 2021), whilst they have 1/10 of the patents that IBM has. What does that tell you? That you don't win in the market by collecting patents for the sake of collecting patents - what a waste of brainpower and money. You win in the market by being smart about the industries/products you go all in for. During the last ten years, the world has seen one of the longest periods of wonderful market returns in the stock market (look at any big tech company, apart from IBM) - if you invested in IBM, you would have lost 50% of your portfolio, since that has been the absolute return since 2010-2012 peak. Sweet.

— The company's agility is similar to the agility of someone same age as IBM.
Advice to Management
• Cut down the bureaucracy. 
• Properly increase the temperature when it comes to investing in the right products and industries. 
• Get rid of the bad weeds. Invest in keeping the good talent. 
• Innovate to win in the market.
• Stop collecting patents like it's a coin collecting competition for grandpas - you are losing with companies 1/10 your age, even though you have all those patents. And what?

review_title: Hard to climb, railroaded into roles when at certain locations
pros:
- Laid back work environment
- Genuinely really nice people to work with
- Fun office environments
- Good work life balance
- Good diversity, as a PoC
cons:
I was railroaded into a certain role that was not Software Developer oriented. This is pretty much just terrible management overall, and ultimately caused me to leave when I couldn't be moved back into development.

Pay is quite low for a company of this reputation and size. Most companies start upwards of 40k+, but IBM starts grads at 30k.

Some projects are too big and too old, and the technological debt is high.

No bonuses.

There's no structure for getting promotions. Generally, moving up a band is subjective, so your manager can keep you at the same level for a long time, for no reason, if you're unlucky.
Advice to Management
Don't put your grads in QA / Level 3 Support when they signed up for a developer role.

pros: Great focus on inclusion, diversity advancement, good salaries at the executive level, overall very good benefits.
cons:
Climate for pay raises and promotions are very limited. In fact, advancement overall is limited. IBM's leadership protects its own while allowing the rank and file to languish. Except for the mega and large clients, IBM's relevancy in the marketplace has lost its luster.
Advice to Management
Find ways to improve the compensation and promotion pipeline for Band 6 to 10. Morale in many organizations is challenging as employees continue to keep their heads down and hope they aren't RA'd. Getting rid of GTS is a great move and should have happened years ago.

review_title: Offers alot of room for growth, pay isnt as competitive as comparable roles elsewhere.
pros: Great management, a lot of room for growth, and tons of resources to develop new skills. I came in as an Application developer but told them I like working with DevOps, they slowly put me on more projects where I can build DevOps skills. Because it's such a huge company with so many positions, you can practically pick a job role you want and slowly move towards it.
cons:
Pay is not as competitive as application developers for other companies. Benefits are so-so. You need to work for IBM for a minimum of 3 years for them to contribute to 401k.

review_title: Work security and work life balance are a huge plus; but pay is quite low
pros:
Friendly colleagues, people who’ve stayed for several years - making it a tight knit group. 
Work life balance - possible to do other things in addition to work (studies/ hobbies/ family time etc)
cons:
Keep buying companies and slowly dismantling them, not investing enough in workforce or the offerings of these acquired companies, therefore losing talent and clients.
Advice to Management
Invest more in people and technology offered - thats the only way the best talent and clients will stay. Yes we’re IBM but its time to realise that we need to offer more than just our name.

review_title: IBM has great products and solutions. Management is in transition and confused.
pros: The products and people are awesome. Diverse, good pay, lots of opportunity to show your abilities.
cons:
Management is confused about the company identity, wants sales people to sell things they are not compensated on, but messaging is where IBM is going leaving clients feeling of abandonment. One size message doesn't fit the width and depth of IBM's product line and service offerings.
Advice to Management
IBM isn't RedHat and top level management really needs to step back and understand the entire business. RedHat was a <$5B annual revenue company and I fear this $70B company is lost in the RedHat message. A message around cloud is great, but its just one part of the business. You are alienating your current customer base, they know it and are upset about prospects of a future for the investments for on premise they have made, and your employees are starting to be lost as to what is expected of them. Not all Client Technical Specialist are able to be RedHat marketing people and give sales pitches on cloud. Besides those of us who understand cloud, understand IBM Cloud is missing some key certifications and credentials for large customers. Techincal engineers that deal with facts not fuzzy stuff. Career paths are of a concern to this group within IBM.
1 person found this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: A good place to work in for a few years
pros: There is a competitive starting salary for graduates, there are lots of very experienced engineers you get to work within the company. There are lots of opportunities to change teams, products or job roles. There’s time allocated to all employees for self-learning (Learning new technical skills, online courses etc..), the company looks impressive on a CV
cons:
Salary stays pretty static, teams working on different components in the same product are a bit isolated from others and this can cause problems when one team makes a change that breaks another teams component without notifying them of the change. Knowledge sharing between team members could be a lot better, there is a high chance of working on a product for two or three years that gets cancelled. Coffee/food/snakes you have to pay for. There’s also a very poor concept of working overtime, you will get your time back in lieu but not cash may not be an option. There’s also a bit of a disconnect from very senior management and regular staff.

review_title: Some teams are great, the company doesn't care about you
pros:
Great WLB
It's possible the RedHat takeover will turn things around over the next 5-10 year
cons:
Compensation is not competitive.
Working in a high pressure, high performing product doesn't yield better compensation -- just more lip service from C Suite.
Raises and bonuses are very small, not guaranteed. Major compensation changes only happen on promotion.
New senior management in Cloud has started "death marches" to meet requirements for things like new compliance standards.
Advice to Management
Without better compensation, you won't attract or keep top engineers. Granting equity as part of compensation is the MINIMUM you can do to make people feel like they have some skin in the game.

pros:
- Fantastic opportunities to learn about many different things
- Rotation between teams is possible
- Lots of very smart people willing to help out
- Generally exciting projects; often you will go from being just one person researching something and the next thing you know it is a large scale team effort across countries
- Pre-covid...travel! Conferences, meetups, etc
- Agile working and good use of communication tools to ensure remote working isn't a problem
cons:
- You will not always be in a role that best suits your previous skills and experience - it depends on the business needs. But it is your career and you can rotate
- Can be stressful when it's deadline time and you're on a mustfix defect - but comes with the territory; you will be challenged
Advice to Management
Let's get our reputation back to what it once was so we can continue to attract and keep the best talent

Recommend

ltant 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Large organisation with large name clients, can lead to good exposure.
Very good job security especially for Graduates / Entry-level positions
Some great and very intelligent people work here.
Cons
Pay is very low compared to a lot of other names in the industries IBM operates in.
Operates more as a lose bundle of companies held together under one banner than a true unified company with a single vision and strategy.
Partners often never 'put pen to paper' and are often just using IBM as an easy to get into transitional job before moving elsewhere.
Slow progression of both salary and responsibility.
Currently going through a split and focusing purely on a cloud and consulting model - not sure they will be able to compete with others in these fields.
Lots of bureaucracy as you'd expect with such a large organisation.

pros: The people I worked with were fantastic. Very nice, will go out of your way to help and teach you. Great work life balance. Relatively high starting salary.
cons:
Maybe depends on where you work since it is a big company, but coming out of school my expectations of a tech company and what I've experience thus far at IBM were very different. I occasionally feel that IBM is behind with the times in some aspects and long term vision is unclear to me. Tech seems archaic. Pay rises aren't great and annual bonuses are almost insultingly low if you're lucky to get one. Doesn't really incentive young people to stay in my opinion, though there are plenty of IBM lifers...
Advice to Management
We have plenty of surveys and engagement etc. but I havent really seen actual change come about with any of them. Listen to your employees (esp younger folk) and take action.

review_title: Constant cuts have made a once long-term attractive employer a risky prospect
cons:
ant cuts have made a once long-term attractive employer a risky prospect
18 Feb 2021 - Principal Offering Manager 
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
The other IBMers you work with are usually talented, friendly people always willing to help.

Flexible hours are favourable, however the vast majority of IBMers work far longer than their contracted hours to get their heavy workload done.
Cons
The company is in a loop of "resource actions" constantly cutting headcount, even in successful and strategic areas such as AI. The morale amongst my peers is the lowest I've ever known it with concern on where the axe will drop next, as cuts are not tied to personal performance so no-one is safe.

Due to constantly reducing headcount while not reducing (and even increasing) workload employees can end up doing the job several people at once. Executives do not reduce expectations when team sizes are reduced, and act with surprise and disappointment if the remaining team doesn't deliver what the old team would have struggled to achieve.
Advice to Management
Stop saying one thing while doing the opposite. If you're investing in AI and cloud then stop reducing headcount and closing development locations. 

Start listening to your customers on what they want, instead of trying to force them to use your platform if they want your software. If they don't like the platform there are plenty of competitive products that they can go to instead.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful

review_title: Good work-life balance but lack of career growth opportunity...
pros:
1. Good Work-life balance. The organization culture promotes "trust" among employers and employees. These are much better compared to any peer Indian IT Service organizations.

2. Excellent learning culture. The organization provides and promotes (including financial support) for learning and growth (including external learnings) for individuals. There are many facilities to upskill and upgrade. Any proactive individual can easily utilize these opportunities to upgrade him/herself. (Most of the cases - organization assistances are no strings attached like 'approval only when a customer wants' which is stickily followed by many other Indian IT Service Organizations)

3. Promotes diversity in a big way. This organization is very good for woman employees as many of its policies and approach are favorable to them. 

4. This is an organization where people stay longer. (specially for those who love to be in a comfort zone)
cons:
1. Lack of Growth for an individual career. Management does not promote a growth mindset. The compensation and yearly hikes are much lesser compared to the market standard. The management encourages mediocrity. This results in a lack of innovation and agility. (though the organization claims otherwise in 'talks')

2. Top heavy organization and incompetent management. Processes are highly bureaucratic, slow, and complex. Too many hierarchies. Everyone seems to be highly insecure and lacks the courage and conviction to make the right decision on the top. CxO level strategy changes too frequently.

3. Most pathetic medical insurance for Indian employees especially if anyone has aged-dependent parents to take care of. (compared to medical insurance provided by other Indian employers)

pros: Lots of smart colleagues. Attracts talent due to name recognition, commercials...?
cons:
Sizable gap between the sunshine spread by C level execs versus the reality of first/second line managers. In my last position, C level said one thing and then first line manager completely disregarded the overall strategy including skills needed for team. The layoff cycle is constant. It's tiresome. No one feels valued. No job security.
Advice to Management
Stop the layoffs. These are indicators of really poor executive management. Why would talent want to join a layoff shop? Also, THOROUGHLY monitor first line managers to make sure strategy, skills are being implemented and embraced. A dinosaur manager just laid me off because I got certified in skills heavily touted by C level. This happened to someone else on my team, too.

pros:
Getting your foot in the door.
A chance of getting lucky and actually learn what you expect to learn(coding, programming, etc.)
cons:
You might get your hopes up and expect too much from this program, not all the apprentices get the same treatment or opportunities. Some apprentices were actually learned to program and were exposed to a vast array of skills. You get an IBM apprenticeship that lists all the skills we were supposed to have learned, yet my team was limited to SAP only.
Advice to Management
Be transparent and disclose all the expectancies. Practice what you preach, constantly you would hear about letting people decide their career future, but when it comes to practice that opportunity is not given.

ltant in Dublin, Dublin
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Flexible hours, no micromanagement, respect, fun people to work with, if you are highly motivated this place will be good to you.
Cons
for a process-driven organization, some processes are dreadful... took me a week to get a new mac when mine stopped working... need an adapter for an external screen.. its been 2 weeks and still, they are working out a correct cost code it needs to be billed to.. (69 euros worth!?). The bullying policy is not existing if your manager is a friend with the second line manager... 4 people complained to HR about one specific manager and noting has been done about it.
Advice to Management
My team is great but I see other teams struggle with managers who are micromanaging them, taking their work and claim as their own, they are bullies and rude to their employees. Their family struggles are reminded to them and reflected in their check point reviews. This is not for all managers but HR should keep a close look if an employee complains to them about a manager...

ltant in Melbourne
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
1. Good opportunities for young people
2. Good exposure to a massive multinational corporation
3. Broad client base in several industries
4. Good learning /skill management system 
5. Good WFH, inclusion and diversity policies
6. Worldwide opportunities for those keen to move
7. High integrity at the core values
Cons
1. Salary is lower than market average
2. Ridiculously small salary increases
3. Nebulous promotion criteria (more politics than merit) that changes often (and you are always behind)
4. New hires make more money than people with same skills and responsibilities (no much financial reward on experience/skills developed) - If you've accepted a lower salary when hired, you will most likely take 10+ years to fix it (most people leave within 2 years)
5. Not the better reputation in Australia (company) and lots of bad attitude from client staff, independent contractors and even ex-IBMers
6. Lots of "clans" and political animals who survive (and make lot of money) just "talking their way" and doing very little.
7. Unfortunately not the company people think it is (not anymore)
8. No matter what extraordinary contributions you've made during your time, you may be made redundant at any time without any compelling reason (or explanation)
Advice to Management
None... The blue machine is so big and old, that they won't listen, and if they do, they won't do anything.

location: São Paulo, São Paulo, São Paulo
cons:
ltant in São Paulo, São Paulo, São Paulo
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Undergoing great (believable) transformation, pro-diversity, being at the forefront of IT development, great access to information (this is a huge), too big to fail.
Cons
Not nimble or even Agile enough, trying to balance the Watson's legacy of providing security to employees with the necessary turnover of the IT business - and giving too much focus on sales people, band 6-8 career progression gap, having a vague evaluation process. Still lacking strong cultural change, away from the "this is how things go around here" mindset.
Advice to Management
Have our executives list a few of our strategic mistakes (it's become a healthy practice), force 360 evaluation process (who knows what feedback I have regarding my superiors which I fear telling them?) - i.e. favor transparency, set a goal for achieving radical transparency at least among top-management. Maybe have our collaborators being tested on the Agile Manifesto randomly.

review_title: Redendancy and being on the outside...
cons:
ltant in Manila, Manila, Manila
Recommend
CEO Approval
Business Outlook
Pros
Pay, Benefits, Global business leader,
Cons
Lack of manager guidance, Tunnel vision
Advice to Management
IBM is too siloed: it is historical and by design, there is a good business reason which is not relevant here. I saw evidence that there is an effort to change this in my time there but it was also in fact how I found my value, easily working across business units (silo's) to get the process fixed or remove redundancies, my issue was recording or proving it. Ever ready with a label IBM calls people like me 'wild ducks' and they admit that we are harder to manage because we at times work against the 'normal' that has made IBM so strong. 

For example, on paper I am an extremely average employee, success factors just could not capture my achievement. So when my manager had to cut a whole team in a redundancy action and let all 16 of us go those of us without perfect SAP records, or good senior friends suffered in the scramble for jobs that occurs every year in 'redundancy season'! It was a sound business decision as we were a mobile team of floating resources, that when not utilized hurt the bottom line of our department! There were only 4 casualties and losing the whole team gone eliminated a potential budget risk of $34,000 per month, a smart move especially 9 months before COVID lockdown in March 2020 when most of us would have been benched quickly. However, I am trying to show this not as a complaint but an observation on how even with a sound process, there is collateral damage! 

Neither my manager nor I managed to retain a copy of page 1 of my redundancy letter in the whirlwind of activity that was my departure. It was a Friday and I had finished my tasks on a project, while I could and perhaps should have hung around for another week but I took the responsible approach and handed over the simple remaining tasks. The project was being cut by about 30 staff and for me, it had been an interesting gap filler! 

I left thinking it was time to look for my next! I messaged my manager to let him know I needed to find another project but was leaving a little early as I had wrapped up efficiently. He insisted on seeing me that day, I was tired and tried to get out of it but it could not wait! The reason he could not wait? He was serving me a redundancy notice and if he waited till the next Monday it would be a new month and I would qualify for an extra months pay! As I said the process was followed but there was no humanism in it. 

It might make sense to most of us, even me a month salary saved is a good brownie point with his boss but it's not the big picture of the individual affected or me! This lack of humane involvement in the process is why my rating of this company has dropped substantially since me employed review. I shall try to briefly explain why I feel poorly dealt with and why I blame a process not a person.

Not seeing the cost savings of my last automation project mentioned above I can only estimate 2-3 CPA qualified FTE were reassigned, I hope! However on the project before as it's the leader I had earned the company more money than they would pay me in 355+ years, at my current rate. Perhaps not a fantastic accomplishment considering where I got the opportunity from, but when I was learning about the world of work last century it would have earned some kind of retention bonus for accomplishment! They never trained me in sales, or design I learned on the job; it could be said they tempted me out of HR to sell and design a product a client was insisting on and then left me to my own devices knowing they had no the intention to market my newly designed product, it was not profitable enough! 

It was not a design flaw it was a flaw in the process, you see nobody could confirm that in 7 years in an HR cost centre I had saved or recovered more money than I was paid, not like the above sample but perhaps 150% of my total salary! Sadly peanuts in the Global Business Service world which meant it wasn't even relevant! If I had fought it and raised these issue I would have struggled with proof and it would be argued I should have recorded this more clearly in SAP success factors, and yes I would agree! Though I was constantly getting edited by managers who did not want to increase my pay with repeated professional assessment increases! 

Siloed was my original point because working across business unit's with ease is what multinationals need, people who ask why an HR mobility team needs a full financial report if we only report details in QBR's internally, getting the initial report from the system meant time saved and no process miss as we did not need all the supporting documents! Moving across BU's means the requirement's at times even the relevance of your activity changes in importance it's really hard to keep track and protect yourself. 

My point is this if you decide to work at IBM retain facts of everything you do ask your manager about your contribution, get a confirmation note. Ask each quarter how should you show progress and achievement at your end of the year, it's important people move a lot if you wait for 6-11months you may have a new manager who can not answer you! 

My advice to managers is talking to your managers until someone is talking to Arvind Krishna and convince him that if you want to have wild ducks who are perhaps not brilliant but are above average then more time must be spent coaching, building employee accomplishment not brushing them under the carpet.
Be the first to find this review helpful
Helpful
Share
Repor

However on the project before as it's the leader I had earned the company more money than they would pay me in 355+ years, at my current rate. Perhaps not a fantastic accomplishment considering where I got the opportunity from, but when I was learning about the world of work last century it would have earned some kind of retention bonus for accomplishment! They never trained me in sales, or design I learned on the job; it could be said they tempted me out of HR to sell and design a product a client was insisting on and then left me to my own devices knowing they had no the intention to market my newly designed product, it was not profitable enough! 

It was not a design flaw it was a flaw in the process, you see nobody could confirm that in 7 years in an HR cost centre I had saved or recovered more money than I was paid, not like the above sample but perhaps 150% of my total salary! Sadly peanuts in the Global Business Service world which meant it wasn't even relevant! If I had fought it and raised these issue I would have struggled with proof and it would be argued I should have recorded this more clearly in SAP success factors, and yes I would agree! Though I was constantly getting edited by managers who did not want to increase my pay with repeated professional assessment increases! 

Siloed was my original point because working across business unit's with ease is what multinationals need, people who ask why an HR mobility team needs a full financial report if we only report details in QBR's internally, getting the initial report from the system meant time saved and no process miss as we did not need all the supporting documents! Moving across BU's means the requirement's at times even the relevance of your activity changes in importance it's really hard to keep track and protect yourself. 

My point is this if you decide to work at IBM retain facts of everything you do ask your manager about your contribution, get a confirmation note. Ask each quarter how should you show progress and achievement at your end of the year, it's important people move a lot if you wait for 6-11months you may have a new manager who can not answer you! 

My advice to managers is talking to your managers until someone is talking to Arvind Krishna and convince him that if you want to have wild ducks who are perhaps not brilliant but are above average then more time must be spent coaching, building employee accomplishment not brushing them under the carpet.

review_title: Big Name company where it is difficult to grow unless you have contacts
pros: Large company. Plenty of opportunities to upskill and reskill. Excellent training resources.Flexible hours.
cons:
Difficult to grow due to bureaucratic nature of company. Very political when it comes to managers who control everything when it comes to your career. Resource managers are the absolute worst who will try to assign you to any project irrespective of your skill or seniority and are not willing to put in any effort to help you get a project, position or location of your choice. It does not matter if you have been rated highly throughout your career there for them. They will try to assign you to the first project available and if you say no, they will escalate the matter. Despite having locations in every country, it is nearly impossible to to get opportunities where you want to go because of the rigid country based structure. For almost every other IT company, it is easy to move to a country that you want to move to if they have a branch there.
Advice to Management
If a resource has been rated highly every year then at least be reciprocative to their aspirations and make efforts for them to be able to meet them by not having to leave the company

pros: Flexible timings, can opt for full time work from home if negotiated properly. The clients are stable and being running for long duration. Has its own framework of certification program which are recognized since it has a Brand associated with it. Better job stability as in case resources get released from one account can be allocated to other account
cons:
Lack of projects with good technology stack. The clients are relatively running their services for long and older platforms. Salary hike is almost neglible which I think is the same for all other IT services company. But there can be situation where one can get 0 % hike as well. Onsite opportunities are the least as they have establishmet in all geographic location. The HR system is opaque so for any unforseen situation, getting a neutral help is very difficult. The appraisal process is very difficult to understand, so you don't really understand whether you are getting a good rating or not.
Advice to Management
Try to work on getting clients from competitive sectors so the technology growth happens within the organization. Work on engaging in providing advanced solutions.

pros: Diverse community, extremely bright people to work with, IBM does so much you can have a career learning and doing many different things all in one place. AI, Data Science and Analytics, Cloud, eCommerce, Collaboration, etc in roles of marketing, product management, engineering, HR, etc.
cons:
IBM of late has struggled to finds it differentiation and focus in market and again be an innovative leader. Much of this is because while it still has longer term strategies they are measured quarterly (or even monthly) and regular reorganization and reactive behavior and change keep them from achieving the persistence needed for long term success.
Advice to Management
Pick a few bets, stick to them over years, do a better job sorting out the changes needed in those areas and addressing them without constant large scale disruption. Arvind, new CEO, seems to be heading in this direction. Time will tell.

review_title: All comp based off base pay
pros: Great benefits and training - IBM never really looks bad on your resume
cons:
Pay - If you are a motivated and industrious hard worker, you are better off elsewhere. Socialized earnings - top and bottom not much difference. Better have a manager who will fight for your commissions. I continually blew out my quota but was given retroactive quota increases - that resulted in negative commission checks! Yes - I am being serious. Explanation: "Since you do so well and were paid in the bonus in the previous quarter, with the increased quota, you were actually overpaid ... so you owe us money." They never made you pay it and tried to make it sound like you were being done a favor when it was 'wiped clean' at the beginning of the next year. Net net - they fund you not off the dollars you sell but at a percentage of your salary. Go someplace that pays you for what you actually sell at a guaranteed rate.
Advice to Management
Fully explain the details of the comp plan and that it is unlikely that you will beat your estimated earnings even in a banner year.
